<div class="word-content">
<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-right:-9.0pt;text-align:center'><a
name="_Hlk157084986"></a><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>GREEK HELPS IN NEW TESTAMENT
INTERPRETATION</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-right:-9.0pt;text-align:center'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Virgil
Warren, PhD</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-right:-9.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:
.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>In
general, Greek raises possibilities of interpretation we would not think from
the English wording. Sometimes the Greek eliminates ideas the English wording
might suggest. The Greek helps us understand why translations differ at certain
points, and alerts us to ambiguities in the original text so we do not get
dogmatic about a certain idea in the passage. Greek awareness enables us to use
study tools like Greek concordance, lexicons, and commentaries that discuss the
original text.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-right:-9.0pt;text-align:justify'><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Typical
Sources of Difficulty in the Greek New Testament</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Second
person plural indicative <i>vs</i>. imperative</span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
These two Greek forms are always the same in any given voice and tense. (a) You
cannot always tell whether the speaker is telling them something or telling
them to do something. Likewise, (b) you cannot always tell whether the speaker
is asking a question that anticipates a negative response (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
<i>you are not supposing, are you</i>) or giving a prohibition (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
<i>do not suppose</i>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>2.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Punctuation
differences</span></u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>. The oldest Greek uncial manuscripts were
written in all capitals and did not indicate punctuation; consequently, (a) situations
arise where full stops could be placed at different points in the statement or
where comma and semi-colon could suggest different thought associations between
parts of the sentence. </span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (b)
Paragraphing problems come up where editors must decide whether to insert a <u>paragraph
break</u> or where such a break should occur.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (c)
Without punctuation, readers cannot always distinguish <u>questions from
statements</u>. (See below a list of such passages.) They cannot tell a
statement from a question unless there are (a) interrogative words preceding,
or (b) the question involves a negative with the indicative, in which case </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>shows
there is a question anticipating a negative response. An indirect question can usually
be identified by the interrogative character of the main clause. </span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Another
typical problem is where direct quotations end because no quotation marks
appear in the original, unedited text.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> On
some occasions, editors must decide whether the text should read </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>or
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
can also be an issue as to whether it introduces indirect discourse or means
because.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>3.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Participles</span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Circumstantial participles can cover for such a wide variety of adverbial
ideas, and Greek writers loved to use them. Participles can cover for time,
means, manner, cause, condition, concession, attendant circumstance, purpose,
result, co-ordinate circumstance. It is sometimes unclear also whether
nominative participles that appear near same-number linking verbs are
periphrastics or separate entries in the sentence. Periphrastic participle
constructions can be unclear as to whether the elements should be taken as
separate items.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>4.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Genitive
case</span></u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
The genitive case in Greek serves to tie one noun <u>grammatically</u> to
another noun. How their referents <u>really</u> relate must be determined from
the nature of the case, which may leave two or more options in some cases. If
the phrase-head noun refers to an action, a typical problem is whether the
associated genitive noun is the subject of that action (subjective genitive) or
the object of it (objective genitive). </span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>5.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Manuscript
variants</span></u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>. A number of textual variants occur in the text of
the New Testament. Often, they cause significant differences in the content of
the statement. </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (our) </span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>and </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(your) </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>are
often confused.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>6.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Article</span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
The rules that govern the Greek article are sufficiently different from the
rules for the English articles that translators and students end up making
different judgments about their presence or absence in given cases.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>7.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Vocabulary</span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
In many instances interpreters have different opinions as to the meaning of
individual vocabulary words. This both leads to, and derives from, overall
theological stances, which form a context for judgments. (a) Whether </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>means
because or that is sometimes unclear because it can introduce an indirect
discourse segment or an adverbial clause (combines with lack of punctuation and
lack of lower/higher case letters). (b) </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>can
mean <i>in, among, in the manner of,</i> and conceivably <i>by.</i> (c)
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>can
be a reciprocal or reflexive pronoun.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>8.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Middle
and passive voice</span></u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>. In the present, imperfect, present
perfect, and pluperfect tenses, the middle and passive voices are the same for
a given person and number.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>9.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Verb
aspects</span></u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>. The present and imperfect tenses can cover
characteristic, iterative, tendential/conative, progressive, continuous, timeless,
and simple action. The future can be progressive, characteristic, or simple
action. The imperfect can be ingressive action. The aorist can be simple,
gnomic, ingressive for statives, <i>etc</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>10.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Gender</span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Declensions cross each other as to what ending signals feminine or masculine at
times, which can make it unclear with names, for example, whether a man or
woman is indicated. </span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>11.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Capitalization</span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Greek uncial manuscripts were written in all capital letters. Consequently,
there are occasions when the editor does not know whether the writer meant a proper
noun or common one. The word is frequently unclear as to whether it should be
capitalized in reference to the Holy Spirit, the human spirit, or one of the
other several applications of the term.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>12.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp; </span></span><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>First
person singular indicative <i>vs.</i> subjunctive</span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
The form of the first singular indicative and subjunctive are the same in the
present, and they are the same for the future indicative and aorist subjunctive
with regular verbs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span style='text-decoration:
 none'>&nbsp;</span></span></u></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In addition
to these brief notations on specific passages, we recommend consulting herein <i>The
Conversational Version: Translation Notes for the New Testament</i><b> </b>as
well as <i>The Conversational Version: Translation Notes for the Old Testament</i>
and the essays under <i>Hermeneutics: Getting the Point.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>Is the
antecedent of <u>whom</u> supposed to be <u>Mary</u> or <u>Joseph</u>? </b>The
antecedent is <u>Mary</u> because the Greek reads </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Consequently, Matthew is not claiming that Joseph was the father of Jesus. The
rest of this context and the account in Lukes gospel make that clear.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> To counter belief
in the perpetual virginity of Mary, interpreters often appeal to until (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
in this verse to show by implication that the couple subsequently had sexual
relations and that the four brothers and at least three sisters were the result
(Matthew <b>13</b>:55-56). <u>Till</u>, however, may appear in the text only to
reinforce the fact that Jesus was virgin born without necessarily implying that
sexual relations began thereafter. Isaiah <b>42</b>:4 says, <i>He will not
fail or be discouraged <u>till</u> he has set justice in the earth.</i></span><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Luke
<b>27</b>:8 says, <i>Wherefore it is called the Field of Blood</i> [Aceldama] <i><u>to</u>
today</i> </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><u><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span></u><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
</span><u><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Till</span></u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
could be influenced by the possible meanings of </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL
style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span lang=HE style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>in
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrew.
</span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span> does not necessarily imply that the action not occurring before
it does then occur after it. That may follow English idiom, but not necessarily
Greek idiom under Hebrew influence. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The evidence <u>for</u>
the perpetual virginity of Mary needs to be shown because nothing in the
biblical record suggests it. It arises instead from Greek philosophical
influence on the subapostolic church. According to Greek dualism, the material
world and its desires were to be depreciated (rather than managed). The seven
children referenced in Matthew <b>13</b> have become Josephs by a previous
marriage to a wife who had died. If that were the case, how does that sizable
group of siblings figure into the trip to Bethlehem, where Jesus was born, and
the following couple years perhaps before the holy family returned from Egypt
and eventually made it back to Nazareth?</span></p>

<i>would not be comforted because they were not.</i></span></p>

eye (as with the imperfect tense).</span></p>

situation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 6:13 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>textual
issue</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does the
conclusion belong on the model prayer: <i>For yours is the kingdom and the power
and the glory forever. Amen</i>?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
difference lies in the manuscripts behind the Latin Vulgate <i>vs</i>. the
Textus Receptus from which they translated the King James Version. The
difference does not come from some doctrinal difference.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 6:27</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>. . . to
add one measure</i> [</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>]<i> to his life
span/height</i> [</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>].</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Luke <b>19</b>:3
uses the word to mean small in stature. Zacchaeus got up in a tree because he
was short, not because he was young.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 11:12</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> voice</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>From the
days of John the Baptist until now, the kingdom of heaven</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(1)<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp; </span></span><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
suffering violence and violent people are seizing it</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(middle)<i></i>;</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(2)<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp; </span></span><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
being forced</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (passive).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Jesus means
that people who are expecting an earthly, political kingdom are straining to
bring it in by military means. They anticipate a Messianic enterprise that
brings about that very thing, and they are ready to join in to free the country
from Roman control.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 13:32 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>comparative
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> degree
adjective</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A mustard seed
is smaller than all the seeds. In the New Testament, the comparative degree
is frequently used in place of the superlative degree on adjectives. There may
be seeds that are smaller than a mustard seed, but Jesus evidently has in mind
seeds that are planted in a garden. Besides, the adjective can carry an elative
value, that is, quite small or very small. The main point is a comparison
between the size of the seed and the plant it produces.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 13:56</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> syntax</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i> . . .
and his sisters, are they not <u>all</u></i> [feminine] <i>with us?</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) Is <u>all</u>
feminine because Jesus had at least three sisters in addition to the four
brothers that are named? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Is <u>all</u>
feminine because the nearest antecedent is feminine, and <u>all</u> as an
adjective cannot be both masculine and feminine so as to cover both brothers
and sisters?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> So two
principles are at odds with each other here: (1) the use of masculine for mixed
reference and (2) forming an adjective according to the nearest antecedent. But
that issue can be set aside because we doubt that a feminine adjective would
cover a mixed group even if it were the nearest antecedent; masculine takes
preference.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 16:18 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syntax</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>You are Peter</span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
[</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>], and on this rock </span></i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>[</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>]
<i>I will build my church.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Is the
antecedent of this rock (1) the content of the confession, (2) Peter, or (3)
Jesus?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Taking the
antecedent as the content of the confession (<u>grammatically</u>) is best
because it stands in third person reference<i>vs</i>. I (Jesus) or you
(Peter). If we maintain our <br>
CIR custom of using that for aforesaid demonstrative in English (rather than
this for to-be-said), the statement becomes, <i>Ill build my church on that
rock.</i> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Obviously,
there is a play on Peters name, something like, <i>As sure as you are Peter,
I will build my church on the fact that I am the Messiah.</i> Adding in the
difference between </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> and </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
when distinguished, we gain the feature ledge rock (</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
over and above detached rock (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>),
Peter. The ledge-rock value recalls 1 Corinthians <b>10</b>:4, where Christ/Messiah
is the rock. Matthew<b> 7</b>:24 has the wise builder putting his house on
ledge rock. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Aside from
syntactical considerations, <u>Jesus</u> as the antecedent would make the point
something like 1 Corinthians <b>3</b>:11 (<u>theologically</u>): <i>No other
foundation can be laid than what is laid.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Peter</u>
as antecedent would make a point similar to Ephesians<b> 2</b>:20, where Paul
speaks of the church as built on the apostles and prophets (<u>historically</u>).
Peter was the most prominent personality among the original twelve (<i>primus
inter pares</i>), although it is questionable whether he would eclipse Paul,
who was added later, <i>I labored more abundantly than all of them</i> (1
Corinthians <b>15</b>:10). Pauls comment references Peter/Cephas, the twelve,
the Lords brother, as well as all those to whom Jesus appeared after his
resurrection. Besides, Paul comes off as the more articulate apostle on
theological matters. He corrects Peter in Antioch (Galatians <b>2</b>:11-21).
In 2 Peter <b>3</b>:15-16, Peter seems to acknowledge Pauls greater acumen in
theological understanding. Historically speaking, Paul has left more written testimony
on doctrinal matters, and he worked more abundantly in regions that had a more
enduring witness to Christ, especially after A.D. 70, when the Romans destroyed
Palestine. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In this
reconstruction we may also note that </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>simply
joins two things, which for conceptual reasons are viewed as facing each other (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
rather than facing forward together (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
or standing back-to-back (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>).
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>can
even join realities that are by nature adversative, in effect covering but. Examples
include Matthew <b>1</b>:19; <b>11</b>:19; Mark <b>12</b>:12; Luke <b>2</b>:51;
<b>4</b>:26; <b>9</b>:40; <b>10</b>:24; <b>11</b>:29, 42, 46; <b>12</b>:21, 40,
47; <b>13</b>:6, 27, 35; <b>15</b>:29; <b>17</b>:22; <b>18</b>:2, <b>19</b>:40;
<b>20</b>:19; <b>21</b>:19; John 7:30; <b>16</b>:32; 17:11; <b>20</b>:14; Acts <b>7</b>:5,
9, 53; <b>9</b>:26; <b>10</b>:28; <b>16</b>:7; <b>22</b>:22; 1 Corinthians <b>12</b>:5;
Revelation <b>1</b>:3; <b>3</b>:1;<b> 9</b>:21;<b> 12</b>:14, 16. So, <u>and</u>
does not say anything about the degree of close association or likeness between
items before it and after it, that is, here between Peter and this rock.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Readers might
note Did Jesus Speak Greek? <i>Biblical Archaeological Review </i>(XIX:3);
May 1993, pp. 18ff.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 16:19</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> future
perfect passive</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> What is bound
and loosed? Is the meaning <i>will have been bound/loosed</i> or <i>will
stand bound/loosed</i>?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Under the
first option, Peter should bind and loose on earth what has already been bound
or loosed in heaven. He is to be faithful in preaching what he has received.
Jesus would give Peter the keys (Matthew<b> 16</b>:19) he was to use; he was
not commissioned to make up his own keys.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Under the
second option, the point is that God will stand by Peters proclamation, with
the understanding, of course, that his message did come from heaven in the
first place. God sticks by his people when they stick by his will. The idea
that Peter could originate matters of faith and practice is not involved here
even under the first option.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The apostles
work was to have the opposite effect of what the Pharisees had been doing: <i>shutting
up the kingdom of heaven</i> by what they taught and enjoined (Matthew <b>23</b>:13).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does the
binding and loosing mean authoritative enactment on his own or gospel
proclamation of what he received? God has never turned over to men the
constructing of doctrines or setting up rules and regulations. Jesus cites
Isaiah <b>29</b>:13 as a rebuff of those who teach as doctrines the
commandments of men (Mark <b>7</b>:7). Paul made a point of telling the
Galatians that what he preached he did not figure out on his own or get from
other people; it came to him as revelation from Jesus Christ (Galatians <b>1</b>:12).
No prophecy in the scriptural sense came about from mens deciding to say this
or that; instead, they spoke from God as moved by the Holy Spirit (2 Peter<b> 1</b>:21).
The church did not originate the New Covenant; its leaders and people are
caretakers of what they received.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
binding (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>) as locking comes from
proclamation, and the loosing (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
as unblocking comes from preaching the gospel. By rejecting the message, people
have sins bound on them. By accepting it, they have their sins loosed. Those
who do the proclaiming set up that situation. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Kindred
passages are Matthew <b>16</b>:18-19; <b>18</b>:18; and John <b>20</b>:23.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 17:21 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>textual
question</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>This kind
does not go out except by prayer</i> [and fasting].<i></i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The preferred
reading in the UBS <sup>5th rev ed</sup> omits the whole verse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
bracketed element is omitted from newer translation because it does not have
the best manuscript support.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Several
cases in the New Testament involve the combination prayer and fasting:
Matthew <b>12</b>:21* = Mark <b>9</b>:29; Luke<b> 2</b>:37; Acts <b>13</b>:3; <b>14</b>:23;
and 1 Corinthians <b>7</b>:5*. Asterisks indicate passages with textual issues.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 18:22 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>translation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Does
the wording mean <u>70 x 7</u> (= 490) or <u>77</u> times?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Obviously,
Jesus meant not to put a set number on the times for forgiving someone. Either
rendering would get that across. In contrasting with Peters number seven
times, Jesus is playing on the numbers in Genesis<b> 4</b>:24 (note<b> 4</b>:15).
There Lamech contrasts Cains being avenged sevenfold with his own
seventy-sevenfold. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
frequentative suffix -</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>attaches
to the seventy, and the seven appears as a separate word. It takes two words to
say seventy-seven in Greek. Presumably 490 would call for attaching -</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>to
both Greek words, so to speak, seventy times seven times rather than the first
multiplied by the second</span><span dir=RTL></span><span dir=RTL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=RTL></span> </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>as English wording seventy times seven would
suggest. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

them. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Did Jesus sit
on the two donkeys or on the garments?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The genitive
plural form for all three genders is the same: </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
So as respects grammar, they could refer to the two donkeys (one feminine,
the other masculine) or to the garments (neuter plural). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (a) The
nearest antecedent is garments. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) There
would be no reason for Jesus to ride both donkeys at the same time even if that
was possible. The mother and colt may have been different sizes, which would
make it </span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>hard</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
to do even as a circus act.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (c) And in <b>21</b>:5
(&lt; Zechariah <b>9</b>:9) can mean even. The same goes for </span><span
dir=RTL></span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=RTL></span></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>in
the Hebrew that Matthew quotes.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 21:42</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> antecedent</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>This</i>
[</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>] <i>is from the Lord.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The English
reading can sound like the rejecting by the builders is from the Lord, that is,
its okay with the Lord. This, however, is feminine gender, which links it to
the phrase-head feminine antecedent: the head of the corner [</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>].
It is the head of the corner that is marvelous to see.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 23:35 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>textual
variant</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The quotation
comes from 2 Chronicles <b>24</b>:20-22. A textual corruption has occurred in
Matthews account since Zechariah son of Barachiah would indicate one of the
minor prophets (Zechariah <b>1</b>:1), whose manner of death is not recorded.
Lukes parallel account of the statement (<b>11</b>:50) omits the words <u>son
of Barachiah</u>. The text of Matthew in Codex Sinaiticus firsthand omits the
phrase, as also do some ancient evangelisteria and Eusebius (twice).
Originally, Matthew probably read, <i> . . . from the blood of Abel the
righteous to the blood of Zachariah, whom you killed between the sanctuary and
altar.</i> Jesus comment covers the first to last murder in the Hebrew Old
Testament, which puts Genesis first and 2 Chronicles in final position.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>

lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(1)
The standard reading of the text considers <i>I am the Christ</i> as
something individuals will be claimingthat they were the Messiah. As such, it
is a statement of <u>direct discourse</u>, the quotation of purported words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(2)
Herbert Armstrong read the text as if the clause in question was <u>indirect
discourse</u>, inferring that those who come will indeed be agreeing that Jesus
of Nazareth is the Messiah, but will deceive many people in their message about
him. This interpretation would be possible from an English translation that omits
quotation marks because English can omit the sign of indirect discourse
(that). Greek, however, does not omit the sign of indirect discourse if
followed by a finite-verb construction like here (rather than an infinitive or
participle construction). Consequently, the proposed interpretation is not
possible, whatever may be said about the idea itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 24:14 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>reference</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Readers often
understand this verse to mean that the gospel will be proclaimed all over the
world before the Lords return. So, as that program nears completion, we can
have greater anticipation of his coming soon.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The immediate
context, however, is talking about the fall of Jerusalem and the end of the
Jewish state in A.D. 70. The word refers to the then-known world, or more
particularly the territory around the Mediterranean Sea, the Roman empire: </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
By the time Jerusalem fell, the gospel had already circulated over that area enough
for Colossians <b>1</b>:5-6 to say, <i>the truth of the gospel that has come
to you like it has in all the world </i>[</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>]<i></i>;
likewise, Colossians <b>1</b>:23, <i>the gospel, which was preached in all
creation under heaven</i> [</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>].
Those words came from Paul during his Roman imprisonment, which would have been
in the early 60s. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The reason
the prediction about preaching the gospel all over the empire is significant,
is that Jesus Messianic movement would not be just another fly-by-night
movement. It relates to Gamaliels observation that what was happening with
Jesus followers was not following the pattern of movements led previously by
Theudas and Judas (Acts <b>5</b>:33-39), who were evidently Messianic
claimants. With the death of those leaders, the movements disintegrated. That
is what we would expect with a person-centered system like Messianism: remove
the person, and the system falls apart. But with the crucifixion of Jesus, his
movement was spreading even more, a difference conceivably explained by his
resurrection.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 24:15</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> capitalization</span></p>

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does it mean
(1) <i>standing in (the) holy place,</i> as in Palestine or in the city of
Jerusalem, or does it mean more specifically <i>standing in (the) Holy Place,
</i>the sanctuary (Holy of Holies) either before or after the Romans demolished
it?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The text goes
on to tell the people in Judaea to flee to the mountains (<b>24</b>:16). It
would be too late to flee anywhere if they waited till the Romans were standing
in the Holy of Holies after advancing into the city. The same could be said
about the beginning of the siege of the city. So understanding the holy place
as a reference to the land may be the best option. When the Romans entered the
Holy Land in A.D. 66, the forewarned disciples would have opportunity to flee.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 24:33</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> implied
subject</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(1<i>)
(you) know that <u>he</u> is near at the doors</i> [the Son of man,<b> 24</b>:30]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(2)
<i>(you) know that <u>it</u></i> [<b>24</b>:14, the end, the coming of the Son
of man, the kingdom<i>] is near, at the doors.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
first option connects Jesus prediction with his personal return.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
second option connects his prediction with what will happen within their own
generation (<b>24</b>:34). The <u>it</u> would be the end of the Jewish state historically
with the spiritual kingdom of the Messiah being near to replace it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 24:33</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> imperative/indicative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>When you
see these things, (you) know that he/it-is near, at the doors.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>First,
is the verb indicative or imperative? The forms for both moods are the same. The
fact that Jesus does not use the future tense may favor the imperative,
although a futuristic present might also be possible. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(1)
His return was not during their lifetime.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(2)
Jesus is speaking to his disciples as if <u>they</u> would see that he/it was
at the doors, though the reference could be taken advisedly to mean whoever is
alive at the time involved. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(3)
The fall of Jerusalem forty years later would be something they could live to
see; they would be about sixty or seventy by then. They could at least see the
preceding developments that Jesus was pointing out as leading up to the fall of
Jerusalem: <i>all these things,</i> matters that would happen in <i>this
generation.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(4)
The preceding verse uses the spring sprouting of a fig tree before summer for
comparison to Jesus reference. So the emphasis seems to fall on what would
happen more than on who was involved in it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Stressing
that connects the present statement with the more distant reference (<b>24</b>:29-31),
a reference to the second coming rather than to the subject addressed in the
immediate verses (<b>24</b>:32-35). The similarity of Messianic claimants arising
ties the two events together and leads to the warning not to be deceived by them.
Claims are false just before the destruction of the city because God was not
going to deliver it. The claims would be false before Christs actual return
because it will be visible to everyone (<b>24</b>:30; Revelation<b> 1</b>:7). Liddle
&amp; Scott, <i>Greek-English </i>Lexicon, p. 447 under </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
indicates that in Attic usage, distant time does not reside in the meaning of
the word itself.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>with
a question anticipates a negative response, <i>Im not the one, am I?</i> So
the words do not ask an informational question as in, <i>Am I the one?</i>
Cp. Mark <b>14</b>:19.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

you drink from it.</i> The cup (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
is indicated in the previous part of the verse; so we assume it (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
is neuter to connect up with </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Less likely is that it indicates by metonymy the contents of the cup, the
wine (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>), which is masculine, making
it masculine also. The form of the pronoun would be the same in either
gender. They drank from the same cup, however uninviting that seems to modern
sensitivities. Using actual wine would have tended to allay concerns about
germs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The accounts
of institution have Jesus taking a cup; so it should be clear that it was
circulated among the apostles assembled. In 1 Corinthians <b>1</b>:17 Paul ties
a symbolic significance to the one loaf. Most naturally that symbolism would
apply to the cup as well.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
