lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(1) <i>Have/take a
guard</i> would mean that <u>Roman</u> soldiers were at the tomb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(2) <i>You have a guard</i>
would mean that <u>Jewish</u> soldiers guarded the tomb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (a) On the <u>Jewish</u>
side, Pilate would be referring to the temple guard that the Jews could use to guard
the tomb, perhaps implying he did not think it important for him to involve
himself in this thing. That was their problem. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) After the
resurrection the </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>went
to the Jews, who assembled the Sanhedrin. Perhaps a Roman guard could have gone
to the Jews because that was their only hope of survival. But a reader may
wonder about the statement, <i>If this comes to the governors ears.</i> If
this was a Roman guard, Pilate would surely have had enough connections with his
soldiers to know what spread among them (<b>28</b>:15).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (c) <i>Have
a guard</i> sounds sensible in English as in, <i>Have a cookie,</i> but that
value for </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>seems
remote. <i>You have a guard</i> is more natural. <i>Take care of it
yourselves</i> would fit Pilates attitude on the matter.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (d) We wonder
what influence the Jews would have had over Pilate to protect Roman guards from
whatever disciplinary measures Romans customarily took in such cases. If they
were Roman guards, why would they have gone to the Jewish leaders when the
angel opened the tomb and Jesus came out? Maybe that would have been their only
hope of getting some credible help against the Roman procurator in this awkward
situation. The fact that the Jewish leaders would vouch for them under such a
lame excuse may have increased its likelihood, especially since they could have
pictured this as a really large contingent of Jesus followers to overwhelm a
guard of sixteen. Under the circumstances, the tendency would have been to bill
this as an insurrectionist Messianic movement. Generally, saying that the
disciples stole the body while they were <u>asleep</u> would have cut no ice
with Pilate and Roman law; and obviously that claim was not intended to (<b>28</b>:14).
It was supposedly made to Jews for popular Jews benefit. The text does not
explain how the religious leaders would persuade Pilate if this matter ever
reached his ears.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (e) It is
doubtful whether Pilate would have put a group of Roman soldiers under the
Jews direction rather than under his own authority.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (f) A
consideration toward the <u>Roman</u> explanation is the meaning of </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
If it has the flavor of custodians, it might fit well with the temple-guard
proposal. However, since it is a Latin loan word and not the more normal word
for guard (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>), the argument accommodates
a <u>Roman</u> designation. </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
appears only in this context in the New Testament. (Matthew <b>28</b>:11; <b>27</b>:65,
66).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (g) Also in
favor of a <u>Roman</u> guard is the fact that the Jews offered them money to
keep this matter quiet whereas they may not have needed to bribe their own
employees. (But this last consideration may be countered by the Jews concern
to stamp out this messianic heretical movement.) One question for the
Jewish-guard theory is why the concern that Pilate would do something punitive
to them for having lost the body of Jesus. The Jewish religious leaders, not
the soldiers, raised this point (Matthew <b>28</b>:14); after all, the leaders
were the ones that involved Pilate in the matter.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The weight,
though, of these considerations favors a Jewish guard.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The root of </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
is associated with lateness, but according to lexicographers, when followed
by the genitive it should be translated after. That should be obvious from
comparisons with the parallel gospel accounts, where the corresponding
activities took place early in the morning<i>. In the end of the Sabbath</i>
would be late in the afternoon because Sabbath ended at sundown. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Cp Mark <b>8</b>:31:<i>
it was necessary for . . . . him to resurrect after three days.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 28:17</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> the
article/vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
could be translated (1) but some doubted or <i>but they doubted.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> O</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>and
other forms of the article can serve as equivalent of a pronoun; so they is a
possible rendering. Some (ASV) is also possible for a free-standing, plural
article. <i>The New Living Translation </i>notes the surprise element in this
note by inserting an exclamation mark at the end.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does doubt
mean they doubted it was Jesus or that they were not sure what all this meant?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Did some of them
doubt because they were too far away to see well, as was the case with the
seven in Christs appearance in John<b> 21</b>:4-12. They may not all have been
close to him, because the text says in next verse that Jesus came to them.
Was he hovering in the air on this occasion when he delivered the Great
Commission? Is the appearance to the five hundred (1 Corinthians <b>15</b>:6)
conflated with this appearance to the eleven? At any rate, they had enough
faith in him to travel more than a hundred miles to Galilee to meet him as he
had promised.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 28:19</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> participle</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Occasionally
someone will say that we should translate this passage <i>as you go, make
disciples.</i> The interest in this rendering comes from wanting to go on and
say that <i>as you go</i> about your daily life, include outreach to the
unconverted. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (a) If that
were the idea, a present participle would appear here as it does in The Mission
of the Twelve, <i>As you go, cleanse lepers, etc</i>. (Matthew<b> 10</b>:5;
cp.<b> 10</b>:7; Luke <b>13</b>:14). A present-tense participle in the
commission would convey the desired characteristic action. Whether the
participle is taken as aspect or time, it does not come out meaning <i>as you
go.</i> In a temporal sense, the aorist participle means <i>having gone, make
disciples.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) Even if
the proposed wording were appropriate for Matthew <b>28</b>, it would not mean
lifestyle evangelism. It would mean that, as you go about your evangelistic
calling, this is what you are to be doing. Jesus is talking to the apostles he
had chosen specifically for the missionary enterprise; he is not talking to the
general church about lifestyle evangelism as typical members carry on their regular
mode of livelihood.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (c) An aorist
participle attached to an imperative verb picks up the imperatival value of that
verb. Luke<b> 7</b>:22 says, <i>Go, report to John what you have seen and
heard.</i> It could not mean <i>as you go, announce to John . . . . .</i>
See elsewhere the aorist participle + imperative in Matthew<b> 2</b>:1, 8, 13, 19,
20, 21; <b>9</b>:18; <b>11</b>:4; <b>17</b>:14, 27; <b>18</b>:15;<b> 19</b>:21;
<b>28</b>:7; Luke <b>16</b>:6;<b> 17</b>:14; <b>19</b>:5, 30; <b>22</b>:8; Acts
<b>5</b>:20; <b>15</b>:36; <b>16</b>:36;<b> 22</b>:16; cp. Mark <b>6</b>:37
(aorist participle + hortatory subjunctive); cp. <b>16</b>:5 (aorist participle
+ aorist indicative). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (d) Send in
the New Testament program means commission (John <b>13</b>:16). Consequently,
it is not a matter particularly of traveling over a distance when the
commission says go. It means to take the initiative in carrying out the
commission.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (e) The
construction serves as an alternate way of saying, </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
+ imperative, which reproduces the Hebrew idiom  . . . </span><span lang=HE
dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span dir=LTR></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span dir=LTR></span>. It amounts to a
formula for ingressive action. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In closing,
Christians do not need a passage of scripture to tell them to do what is
obviously good to do. A text does not have to mean such and such just because
such and such is true.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Matthew 28:19 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>finite
verb</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
. . . </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) Make
disciples is the only finite verb; therefore, it is the most important idea in
the Commission.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Make
disciples is in a sequence after go and before two participles. All four
verb forms make a series of actions that correspond with the order of the
verbals: go, make disciples, baptize, teach.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> As to (1),
grammatical independence does not necessarily indicate greater real <u>importance</u>
or independence. Instead, grammatical levels show the speakers arrangement as
affected by his flow of thought, what comes to mind first, the purpose of the
present communication,<i> etc</i>. A better tack would be to think of make
disciples as the <u>general activity</u> that involves the other actions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) A
sequential reading of the last three verbals fits with the belief that basic
teaching precedes baptism, which would tell against infant baptism. But
whatever may be true about that point, the three activities at best fit with it
rather than show it. That conclusion about the candidate for baptism comes
first from other considerations. Interpretation theory says that lists are not
necessarily sequential, parallel, exhaustive, or homogeneous. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Taking make
disciples as the large concept of which the other actions are aspects makes a
better connection with the meaning of the cognate noun </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
a disciple. Jesus disciples were more than a retinue of learners who had not
yet come to the point of commitment to him as Lord and Savior. This latter
meaning is the one </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>becomes
if the verb is in real sequence with the preceding and succeeding verb forms. Admittedly,
sequence is involved in that going will precede the rest, and teaching them
everything will follow commitment to Christ in baptism, but reducing </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>to
gathering hearers goes beyond the requirements of the situation and the meaning
of the word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> If we suppose
a meaning correlation between the verb </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>and
cognate noun </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>, then </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>does
<u>not</u> mean preliminary teaching prior to commitment. Not only is </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>not
limited to preliminary learning, but one is hard pressed to find <u>any</u>
case of its meaning auditor rather than adherent. With the verb, note Matthew
<b>13</b>:52 (<i>scribe, who has also become a disciple of the kingdom of
heaven</i>); <b>27</b>:57 (Joseph of Arimathea, who had become a disciple of
Jesus); Acts <b>14</b>:21 (<i>having evangelized that city and made many
disciples, they returned . . . </i>). Matthew <b>28</b>:19 is the only other
example of this verb.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Since </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>occurs
so infrequently (only four times), it is more likely to share the meaning of
the cognate noun (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
than if the verb occurred hundreds of times, thus able to slant itself in
directions more specific than its cognate noun. It is also likely that the verb
and noun are close in meaning because parallel passages in Matthew and John
switch with each other. John <b>19</b>:38 says, </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
[</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>] </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Matthew <b>27</b>:57, however, says, </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Furthermore, in short scope the verb and noun interchange in Acts <b>14</b>:21-22:
<i>having made many disciples, they returned to . . . Antioch [of Pisidia],
strengthening the souls of the disciples.</i> In <b>14</b>:28 Luke mentions
again that when Paul and Barnabas got back to Antioch (of Syria), <i>they were
spending no little time with </i></span><i><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>he
disciples.</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In this same context, <b>14</b>:21
precedes <i>making disciples</i> with <i>having preached the gospel </i>(</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>);

cannot suffice here because another contextually legitimate construction of
thought applies.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 10:11-12</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> meaning
of the present tense</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>If he
divorces his wife and marries someone else, he commits adultery against her.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> It has been
claimed that the tense of the Greek verb commits adultery can indicate <u>continuous</u>
action (present tense) or one-time action, a so-called <u>aoristic</u> present.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Grammar does
not settle this and like cases. The verb form is what it is, and a reader
cannot tell which is meant except by context or the nature of the case.
Furthermore, the present tense can indicate <u>iterative</u>, <u>progressive</u>,
or <u>characteristic</u> action. The verb tense does not particularly have
anything to do with how long the real action lasts or whether it happens more
than once. It should be clear from the kind of thing that is happening here
that Jesus is describing what a husband is doing. He is not distinguishing
between a first-time adultery that is no longer adultery thereafter! Jesus is
saying that a husband cannot avoid the guilt of adultery by divorcing his wife
i to marry someone else. In the spirit of things, doing that amounts to the
same thing as adultery.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 10:14</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> meaning
of the present tense</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1<i>) of
such is</i> [present time] <i>the kingdom of heaven.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>of
such is </i>[description] <i>the kingdom of heaven.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Description
is the more natural reading: the kingdom of heaven is made up of people like
these children. The time idea is aside from considerations here. That can be
decided on conceptual grounds.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> It is seldom
wise to decide large ideas based on a single word, especially when that word
can be taken in more than one way, as with a present-tense Greek verb. At best,
the present tense provides five or more options to choose from, depending on
doctrinal matters decided by clear grounds from elsewhere.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Compare
Matthew <b>19</b>:14; Luke <b>18</b>:16; Acts <b>2</b>:39.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 11:24</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> meaning
of the aorist tense</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Everything
you ask for in prayer, believe that you received (them), and they will be to
you.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Textual
variants here say (1) <i>you received/have-received</i> [aorist indicative],<i>
</i>(2) <i>you receive/are-receiving/do receive</i> [present indicative],<i></i>
(3) <i>you will receive</i> [future indicative].<i></i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Since the
aorist indicative seems to have the best support, it makes sense to take this
statement as a timeless aorist. Such an aorist usage is reminiscent of the
Hebrew perfect used for something future viewed as certain, as good as having
occurred. The force of the promise is akin to the future perfect passive in
Matthew <b>16</b>:19 understood as emphatic certainty. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 14:51-52</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Naked
probably means wearing only undergarments; cp. John <b>21</b>:7, where Peter
dived into the sea naked. Presumably he would not have arrived before Jesus
without any clothes on.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 15:2</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> idiom</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mean
yes or you say that; I dont. See the treatment at Matthew <b>26</b>:25.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 15:2</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> question/statement</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Could this be
a question rather than a statement? It would have the force of saying, <i>Are <u>you</u>
saying this or is this at the instigation of someone else? </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In this case,
the form of written words would be the same. It remains a judgment call by the
reader.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 15:28</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> textual
variant</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Some
manuscripts add, <i>And the scripture was fulfilled that said, He was counted
with lawless ones. </i>The addition is in Luke <b>22</b>:37 &lt; Isaiah <b>53</b>:12.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 15:39 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>article</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>This
man was (a) son of God.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Truly
this man was (the) son of God.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) <i>Truly
this man was Gods son.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The first
option might be appealing on the assumption that the centurion was a pagan with
no conviction regarding the deity of Jesus, an unknowable point. This
phraseology could carry a kind of value: that is the kind of man he was. John
<b>10</b>:36 fosters this reading because Jesus connects it with the kind of
person he claims to be.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
option could represent the evangelists wording as affected by Hebrew idiom. The
son of God would be covered by <i>son</i> in the construct followed by <i>God</i>
in the absolute state: </span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
dir=LTR></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span>. A noun in the construct cannot carry the Hebrew article; so
option (2) would be a possible value. Hebrew is involved because a presumably
Hebrew writer is telling what happened. Even in Greek, the son of God could
be understood as the format for a name.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The third
option may be the best English expression because it avoids the <i>the</i>/<i>a
</i>distinction. Cp. Matthew<b> 27</b>:54. Besides, it allows the anarthrous
Greek noun <i>son</i> to imply kind-of/quality <i>vs</i>. identity as in the
first option. In John <b>10</b>:36 Jesus says, <i>I am Gods son</i> [</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>].<i></i>
He would not likely mean that he is a son of God among others, although that
possibility is not entirely eliminated, since he has just quoted Psalm <b>82</b>:6,
<i>You are gods</i> [</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>],<i></i>
a reference to judges in Israel.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 16:7</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Tell his
disciples, and/especially Peter.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Since Peter
was in fact one of Jesus discipleseven the most prominent one, the text would
not be referring to him as someone besides the disciples. The emphasis could
come as a reassurance to the one who had denied Jesus three times. It could
also anticipate Peters role in bringing the rest of the disciples back into
confidence about Jesus after his crucifixion: <i>Once you have returned [to
confidence], establish your brothers</i> (Luke <b>22</b>:32).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 16:9-20</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> textual
issue</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> There
is no doctrinal issue involved in the pericope except the fear that it promotes
snake handling. But the meaning of that promise need not be more than what
happened with Paul on the island of Malta or what Jesus had promised the
disciples after the Mission of the Seventy (Like <b>10</b>:19).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Virtually
everything in this questioned section already appears in the other gospels.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark 16:18</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> future
tense</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The future
tense need not be made more than a prediction of what can happen. To take it as
an imperatival future conjures up tempting the Lord your God because there is
no value in the act itself and borders on exhibitionism. An ambiguous statement
cannot serve as the basis for a belief.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

</span>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:center'><b><span style='font-size:
14.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>LUKE</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Luke 1:3 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> clarification</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>to write
to you <u>in order</u>, most excellent Theophilus, <u>that</u> you . . .</i>
[ASV].<i></i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> So stated,
the verse sounds as if in order combines with that to say in order that.
But they stand separate in the original, <i>to write to you <u>in an orderly
fashion</u>, most excellent Theophilus, <u>in order that</u> you . . . .</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Luke</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <b>1:4</b> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>in order
that you might know the certainty about the things in which you were
instructed.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The word for
instructed means orally instructed. It is the word from which English gets
the term catechism/catechetical (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>).
The verse emphasizes the value of a written account.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Luke 1:36</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Elizabeth,
the mother of John the Baptist, is called a </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>of
Mary the mother of Jesus. The two genealogical lists of Matthew and Luke are
usually reconciled by saying that they are the genealogies of Joseph and Mary
respectively. If so, then Mary was a descendant of David, hence, of the tribe
of Judah; whereas Elizabeth was of the daughters of Aaron (Luke <b>1</b>:5),
hence, the tribe of Levi. Since Johns father Zechariah was also a Levite, both
of Johns parents descended from Levi and Jesus parents were both descended
from Judah. Mary and Elizabeth could not be cousins, as the King James Version
reads in Luke<b> 1</b>:36. Furthermore, the significant age difference between
Mary and Elizabeth does not fit particularly well with their being cousins.
Finally, the word does not specifically mean cousin (at least in English today)
but kinsman. When cousin is meant, Paul uses the expression </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(Colossians
<b>4</b>:10). </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>s
a cognate of </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>, which is also
less specific than cousin. Elizabeth could be related to Mary more distantly
if either one of their mothers was from the other persons tribe. A man did not
have to marry within his tribe.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Strictly
speaking, Luke does not call Quirinius a legatus, or governor. He calls him a
leading one (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>).
He does not carry a title but is described as someone responsible for a
function.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Luke 2:7 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>translation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
<i>She brought forth her firstborn son.</i> An alternate translation has
been, <i>She brought forth her firstborn, a son.</i> That is true, as we know
from the record, because Mary did not have any daughters before Jesus. The
grammar, however, has two modifiers joined to </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>:
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>and
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
one genitive and the other a second-attributive adjective. The genitive
modifier more usually follows its noun, hence, her son rather than her
firstborn, which leaves the firstborn as a substantive adjective: <i>her
son, the firstborn.</i> If the writer is going to say both her and
firstborn as modifiers, her can come before the firstborn. </span></p>

Sometimes people mis-explain the point of a real condition by saying here<i>,
If you are the Son of God [and you are], tell this stone to become bread.</i>
The point of real is that it is <u>treated as real</u> for communication purposes,
for the sake of argument. If you are an American citizen, prove it. A speaker
would not be implying and you are; he would not be asking for proof if he was
admitting that the other person was an American citizen. </span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>The
kingdom of God is <u>inside</u> you<sup>pl</sup>.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>The
kingdom of God is <u>among</u> you<sup>pl</sup>.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) <i>The
kingdom of God is <u>inter</u>personal.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> We wonder
whether Luke uses this unusual word to express an unusual idea. The preposition
occurs elsewhere only in Matthew <b>23</b>:26, <i>Clean first the <u>inside</u>
of the cup,</i> where it must mean the inside. <u>Inter</u>personal would be
<i>in/among you</i> in a specialized manner: <i>n between</i> persons <i>vs.
</i>in a territory, defined by persons rather than territory, race, political
definition. It is in the realm of persons, not place or power.<i> </i>A person
might wonder what it means to say the kingdom is inside yousubjective, in
your heart (?), in your head. Maybe it could imply that the kingdom of God is
rooted in the characteristics of persons, which are internal and expressed in
connection with others who have those attitudes and motives. But the kingdom
itself does not consist of those features; it is rooted in them.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Luke 18:8</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> the
article</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>When the
Son of man comes, will he find faith/the-faith [</i></span><i><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span></i><i><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></i><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>]
on the earth?</span></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In the
interests of pure Christianity, interpreters have taken the question as an
implied warning that the faith will need to be restored because it will be
perverted over the years before Christs return. In English vernacular, the
expression gets applied to relatively minor differences that exist between
Christian movements or denominations. This approach could include later
variations between people equally committed to Christ and the scriptures. But
the Greek article marks contrast/identity, not necessarily definitenessas one set
of individuals <i>vs.</i> another, that is, here one faith/denomination <i>vs</i>.
another.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The first
understanding contrasts faith with unfaithfulness on the earth, faith rather
than the Jewish Messianic expectancy of a political entity, with Judaism,
gnosticism, Gentile religions, or various kinds of syncretism, including
Judaizing efforts. It would be faith in him as Messiah <i>vs</i>. a contrast of
any sort. The <i>New Living Translation</i> renders, <i>How many will he find
on the earth who are faithful to him.</i> The rendering marks a concern for
turning off from Christ in any direction.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The choice
between the two renderings does well to consider how Jesus question relates to
the Parable of the Unjust Judge, which he has just told. The connection may
well be that Jesus wonders whether, when he returns, he will find people will <u>trust/rely
on</u> God (through Messiah?) to give them justice and pray to him for it (cp. <b>19</b>:1).
Other considerations may be real concerns, but Jesus question here deals with a
basic, behavioral matter among people and their relationship to God.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>If I have
wronged anyone, I restore (it) fourfold.</i> Is this a characteristic
presentwhat his practice has been, or a futuristic presenthis pledge for the
future. This had probably not been his (known) practice, or he would have had a
better reputation among the people. He seems to have been so enthused over his
encounter with Jesus that with abandon he makes a pledge about the future.
Something of this usage can occur in English: <i>If hes done that for my
daughter, Im giving them my blessing in marriage.</i></span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> This

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>They got
up that very hour and returned to Jerusalem, and found the eleven gathered
together and them that were with them, <u>saying</u><sup>pl</sup>, The Lord is
risen indeed, and hath appeared to Simon.</i> ASV</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> How saying connects
to the previous wording seems unclear at first as to whether it was the two
from Emmaus or the ones they met in Jerusalem who said the Lord had appeared to
Simon. The reader can probably figure out that the eleven and others in
Jerusalem were telling the Emmaus travelers, not <i>vice versa</i>, because
Peter himself was in the eleven. The participle is accusative masculine plural,
modifying the ones they met in Jerusalem, not nominative masculine plural, as
would make <u>saying</u> modify the two who rose up, returned, and found. A
less literal translation could clarify, <i>with them, who said . . . .</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Luke 24:47-48 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>syntax</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does <i>beginning
in Jerusalem</i> connect with the following or preceding words? The UBS <sup>5th
rev ed</sup> and the Westcott and Hort text choose the nominative masculine plural
for the participle beginning, which connects it with the upcoming <i>you are
<u>witnesses</u> of these things </i>in verse 48. The accusative
masculine/neuter singular reading could perhaps connect with the abstract idea
in the infinitive <i>to be preached</i> (</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
or as a masculine accusative singular connect loosely with the Messiah (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
in verse 46.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

the world.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Translated
the first way, the present-tense verb is an example of tendential/conative
present, has the capability of. It reinforces the idea that the gospel is for
every person. The second way can more easily be read to harmonize with the
doctrine of universalism, the belief that everyone will be saved. Even the
second way, of course, could describe the potential that is in the system
without addressing the issue of what actually happens in the system. Since the
rest of scripture is clear that not all people are saved, we read this verse in
light of that clear teaching elsewhere.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
issue in this verse is the grammatical connection for coming.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>Coming
into the world</i> modifies <i>light</i>: <i>He was the true light . . .
coming into the world.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Coming
into the world</i> modifies <i>every man</i>: <i> . . . the true light that
enlightens every man coming into the world.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> There is no
article on the participle. Its absence could be explained two ways. In keeping
with the first translation, coming (taken as neuter) could be construed
adverbially: <i>He was the true light that enlightens every by coming into the
world.</i> In keeping with the second translation, coming (taken as
masculine) could be anarthrous because the noun it modifies has no article,
that is, person. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Person is
the nearer antecedent. We would think that an author would realize that he was
creating an ambiguity by word arrangement that called for a modifying phrase to
jump over the nearer possible antecedent to modify a more distant one.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In contrast

115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL

to mean mankind <i>vs</i>. other orders of being. The combined idea is that
those (or he) who are begotten are not the fruit of physical drives nor a
husbands decision to beget a child. Neither are they physically involuntary
nor mentally planned.</span></p>

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The term can
mean <i>the only one of its kind.</i> Jesus was the unique son of God. The
word applies only to Jesus in Johannine literature: John <b>1</b>:14, 18; <b>3</b>:16;
1 John <b>4</b>:9. Luke otherwise uses the word three times<b>: 7</b>:12; <b>8</b>:42<b>;
9</b>:38. Once it appears in Hebrews (<b>11</b>:17) to refer to Isaac as
Abrahams only son, even though Ishmael was also his son biologically, hence,
the only one in his category, unique. Only son plays on a derivation from the
root </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The root </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
carrying a double </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>, may also have a
background in </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> in application to
Jesus. It may be questionable whether a single-double </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(or
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Jesus

its class</u>: <i>In America <u>the</u> president needs to be thirty-five
years old.</i> In current usage, American English is more likely to use the
indefinite article: <i><u>A</u> president needs . . . .</i> So in this verse,
Jesus <i>knew what was in a person.</i> The English wording with or without
a for Greek the article ends up meaning about the same thing. English would
not say the man because he was not addressing a specific/definite man.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In favor of
the second is the meaning of the suffix, which appears on directional adverbs.
Furthermore, it fits so nicely the character of the kingdom that Jesus was
bringing, because it was not a political kingdom like the Jews expected; it was
not <i>from below.</i> Paul says to put our minds on things above where
Christ dwells at the right hand of the Father (Colossians <b>3</b>:1-4), and
life and <u>ascended lifestyle</u>. Our citizenship is in heaven (Philippians<b>
3</b>:20). It is to be a <u>resurrected lifestyle</u> (Romans <b>6</b>; 1 Corinthians
<b>15</b>). The eternal beyond the grave leads to the transcendent above the
grave. It is an omniscient viewpoint in contrast either to Jewish political
nationalism or Gentile fleshliness. While in the flesh, we live in terms of
what transcends flesh and guides the use of it; we live a <u>spiritual
lifestyle</u> based on spiritual values.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
