line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Perhaps the
ideas of transcendent kingdom and new beginning could be joined by saying that
we are to be born againfrom above, this time. It is a starting <u>over</u>
from a <u>transcendent</u> orientation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In <u>the
second</u> arrangement, occasionally readers connect water with male semen
for physical birth plus be born of S/spirit. There would hardly be a need to teach
people to be born physically before they can enter the kingdom of God. People
have to exist to do anything, no commandment needed. It is a proposal
sometimes raised to offset another connection brought into this text regarding Christian
baptism (water) followed by the gift of the Holy Spirit. This last idea seems
more relevant than the previous one, but it also seems like too much of a
concretization to fit in a discussion about principles of operation. There is
also no contextual cue for that point. Baptism as commitment to the Messiah and
forgiveness in consequence of that commitment (Acts<b> 2</b>:38), is some three
years off from this conversation near the start of Jesus ministry. A closer
link might be to Johns baptism unto repentance for remission of sins, also a
spiritual consideration <i>vs</i>. racial descent (Matthew <b>3</b>:8-9).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The Greek
plural replaces the Hebrew dual form regularly used for water. New Testament
Greek does not use any dual Greek forms, so dual Hebrew words like water (<span
lang=HE dir=RTL></span><span dir=LTR></span><span dir=LTR></span>, waters)
and heaven (</span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span>, heavens) regularly show up as plurals in Greek. Many springs
still amounts to much water, whether so noted because Johns big crowds needed
lots of water to drink or because immersion calls for more than a little water.
The form of baptism as immersion, appealed to in this passage, has been the
motivating influence for finding some other explanation for the supply of water
noted here. See <i>What the Bible Says About Salvation</i>, pp. 364-65.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>John 4:9</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>have no
dealings with Samaritans</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>do not
use</i> (utensils) <i>in common with Samaritans</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The verse is
the authors explanatory note on the Samaritan womans response to Jesus
request for a drink. Her initial comment was a more general one regarding
Jesus request, not how she could honor the request without using a shared
utensil. There is a water pot in the episode and the womans comment that Jesus
has nothing to draw water with. Common utensils would make a particular
reference in place of a general one (no dealings) with Samaritans. There was
a strained relationship between Samaritans and Jews; yet they evidently carried
on business dealings together, so their lack of relationship was not absolute;
note the Parable of the Good Samaritan (Luke<b> 10</b>:30-37). The womans
comment addresses his request, not how she could fulfill it without using a
defiled bucket. Jesus returning comment is likewise a general one instead of
setting aside the smaller issue as perhaps unimportant to him. The New
Testament makes clear the general antagonism, so taking the authors
interpolation as general makes sense. In addition, we wonder how likely the
author would be to inject an explanation for Gentiles about a small matter about
utensils when a bigger issue was at stake: the generalized antagonism existed
between the two populations. Of note as well is the absence of any reference to
utensils in the Greek itself, and that is what would carry the dative case in a
statement about not sharing utensils. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> We call <b>3</b>:9
the authors interpolation rather than part of the womans statements. She
would have had no call to remind Jesus of such a fact.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The verb here
(</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>) is a once-used word (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
in the New Testament. Lexicons for classical and Hellenistic Greek cite
references for both ranges of meaning in the word, the wider one perhaps
developing from the more narrow one.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>God is

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The absence
of the article emphasizes the nature of God as spirit, which in this instance
means that he is not limited geographically to Mt. Gerizim or Mt. Moriah. In
English, we could say a spirit and mean that is the kind of being he is. The
absence of the English article seems preferred here because Gods individuality
is not so much the issue as his not being limited to one place or anotherspiritual,
transcendent.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

0in;margin-left:1.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-1.5in'><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>John
5:3b-4</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> textual
variant</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
Textus Receptus adds, <i> . . . waiting for the moving of the water: for an
angel of the Lord went down at certain seasons and troubled the water; whoever
then first after the troubling of the water stepped in was made whole, with
whatever disease he was held.</i> The Received Text was the edited text
available to the translators of the King James Version. It did not include a
number of important manuscripts discovered after that time.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>If
the passage had integrity, we wonder whether God would set up such a situation
for receiving a blessing. Where also would people learn about such a pattern?
It would not be a question of fairness exactly, since in our own day the
believers in one part of the world may be starving while those elsewhere are
enjoying the finest cuisine. The difference is that this arrangement would have
been established by God, not brought about by man.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

0in;margin-left:0in'> <span

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-indent:.5in'><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>

lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>

have opted for the harder reading, a standard principle textual critics use in
sorting between readings.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>In
favor of regarding the verb as a futuristic present is that Jonah did come from
Galilee. The Jewish leaders evidently mean that no prophet is predicted to
arrive from that area. It could mean that prophets typically do not come from
Galilee (characteristic present), but that meaning would not have much value for
delegitimizing Jesus as a prophet from there. His credentials were what they
were. The real issue was that <u>Messiah</u> was not to come from Galilee, a
point reinforced by saying that <u>no</u> prophetican even wider
observationwas to come from there.</span></p>

would send the wrong message, especially in a gospel intended more for Gentile
audiences.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The claim has
been made that the statement reflects a later time than Jesus ministry when
the high priest had to be bought each year because the Romans had made that the
case. But the time words are in the genitive, which means time during, not in
the accusative, which means extent of time. <i>Being high priest during that
year</i> says nothing about his term of office. If the claim were true, we
would perhaps expect accusative-case time words here.</span></p>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> question/statement</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-indent:.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(1) <i>and what shall I say, Save
me from this hour?</i> [<i>Is that what I should say?</i>]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-indent:.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(2) <i>and what shall I say? Father,
save from this hour?</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Since
this hour is the reason for his coming into the world, we would not expect Jesus
to say wholeheartedly, <i>Deliver me from this hour.</i> We would expect the
meaning to be as (1) states it. We do have the Lords threefold prayer in the
Garden for the Father to deliver him from this time. That frankly reveals the
reality of the foreboding our Lord felt at the prospect of crucifixion. So with
his feelings he did not want to undergo this agony; but with his will, he chose
to let the Fathers will override his own preference. So the prayer serves as a
realistic model for us all to override our similar feelings of foreboding by willing
to carry out our commitment to the Father in such a dire circumstance. In
principle, God could perhaps have decided to structure the basis for salvation
some other way; but inasmuch as he calls on us to undergo even agonizing death
to maintain our righteous relationship to him, it was only appropriate that the
Savior we commit tofor being considered righteous like himto carry his out
obedient righteousness to that same level. If the Father was going to let Peter
be crucified, how would it look for the perfectly righteous One we are to
commit to to be delivered from that fate? We can say it was an interpersonal
necessity for the Father to let Christs crucifixion take place, given the rest
of his will for mankinds obedience.</span></p>

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span

the antecedent of </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
not </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The

lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
in the immediate context. It is simpler to see the pronoun reference to the
masculine title than to the neuter </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>If
we are interested in finding an argument for the personality of the Holy Spirit
in this context, we do better to note that Comforter indicates a personal
rolethat of serving as an advocate. The alternate reading in Ephesians <b>1</b>:14
would be a more likely example of a masculine pronoun reference to the Holy
Spirit; <i><u>who</u> is an earnest of our inheritance.</i> See under that
reference below.</span></p>

"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>that
of <u>quality</u>, <i>i.e</i>., he will guide you only in the truth (inerrancy);
or is it <u>quantity</u>, <i>i.e</i>., he will guide you in all the truth (that
concerns the Christian calling), hence, no more revelation after the apostolic
era? We do well not to adopt an unclear reading because it would be useful to making
some point, in this case the end of new revelation with the original apostles.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>+
dative <i>vs</i>. </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>+

less expected, reading. The difference is that in the former the Spirit would
guide the apostles <u>in</u> the truth (divine guidance) whereas the latter
would have him guiding them <u>into</u> the truth (revelation). In Hebrew, the
same prefixed preposition (</span><span lang=HE dir=RTL style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span dir=LTR></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><span
dir=LTR></span>) would have appeared in the preposition slot whether Jesus
meant </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>or
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Both in and into make sense, so doctrinally the issue is indeterminate.</span></p>

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
Greek carries a preposition here, which strengthens the idea of <u>source</u>
more than <u>description</u> that the English of is covering. Where something
comes from determines the character that it has. Matthew uses kingdom of
heaven to replace kingdom of God in the other synoptics, where the latter
term appears and the former never does. Matthews terminological adjustment contrasts
with the kind of kingdom the Jews were expecting with the kind of kingdom the
Messiah actually came to establish.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Premillennialists
take this as a confirmation of their view of the millennial kingdom. Inasmuch
the millennium is not part of the gospels witness, we take it as a switch-out
term for kingdom of God and refers to the kingdom Christ is going to set up
at Pentecost, the church. Christ comments to Pilate that his <i>kingdom is not
of this world,</i> indicate that he is not working to establish the kind of
kingdom that Pilate would need to worry about. Jesus was not an
insurrectionist against the Roman empire for establishing an independent Jewish
kingdom.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>John 18:37</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indirect
discourse</span></p>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Of
is a better translation because Preparation evidently became the term for
Friday rather than the act of preparing, and Passover refers to the week-long
feast of unleavened bread.</span></p>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> textual

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>John
says that it was about the <u>sixth</u> hour when the trial of Jesus was still
going on, whereas Matthew 27:45; Mark <b>15</b>:33; and Luke <b>23</b>:44 say
that the was crucified at the <u>third</u> hour. Some ancients suggested that a
copyist misread the digamma , meaning six, for gamma </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
meaning three. The explanation seems inadequate. In general, John uses Roman,
while the synoptics use Jewish, notations of time. So Jesus got to Sychar about
noon. See <i>e.g</i>., Gleason Archer, <i>Bible Difficulties</i>, pp. 363-64. </span></p>

12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>often
means to pick up; so it has been suggested that the stone was picked up and
carried away from the tomb. But in this instance </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>could
not mean carried away because the other accounts say rolled away, </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Roll away and carry away are parallel kinds of actions Consequently, one
term is broad enough to include the other, which we know from elsewhere with </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
It can simply mean remove: <i>in order that the one who had done this deed
might be removed from your midst</i> (1 Corinthians <b>5</b>:2). Compare <i>Away
with him! Crucify him!</i> (John <b>19</b>:15 = Luke<b> 23</b>:18 = Acts <b>21</b>:36;
<b>22</b>:22). Jesus told the ordinary men with him to </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>the
stone from Lazarus tomb (John <b>11</b>:39), so supernatural strength need not
be involved.</span></p>

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>as

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>, says that </span><span

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>rather

"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Another
reconstruction has it that Jesus switched to </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>as

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>and
persisted with </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>. </span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> It grieved Peter

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>).
Maybe the switching was for variety or rounding out the general sense of
relationship between the two men. The same goes for the </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-</span><span

shift and the </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>shift.

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Probably the
best take is not to make too much out of the shifts. Peter does not change his

the triple question provides a rectifying opportunity for Peters triple
denial. There need be no more significance to the shift here than there is
between the two Greek forms of the set designation the disciple that Jesus
loved (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Do
you love me more than</i> [you love] <i>these?</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) <i>Do
you love me more than</i> [these things]<i>?</i> (the fishing business)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The first
option has the advantage of giving a rationale for the directives to feed Jesus
sheep, especially if my sheep includeor isthe disciples present. It sounds like
Luke<b> 22</b>:32, <i>Once you get turned around, strengthen you brothers.</i>
Feeding the other lambs and sheep would call for having greater love than the
others had. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
option raises a seemingly unlikely point. Peter does not strike us as someone
who would be swayed by what the other apostles would think or do</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The third
option might have some relevance since Peter had prompted the others to go
fishing while they waited for the Lord to show up as promised. The point of the
question would be something like, <i>Do you love me more than you love the
fishing business?</i> It would recall Jesus original calling in which he
would have them fish for people. But the fishing business has not been part
of the conversation here; it is only an earlier part of the circumstance.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>John 21:24</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> 
editorial <i>we</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> There seems
to be no need to take these as an editorial insertion by the Johannine
community. No manuscript evidence suggests it was an addition. The most
natural inference is that this is an editorial we used by the author since
the next verse says, I suppose. As far as Greek is concerned, the question is
how typical editorial we was in writers from that era.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The King
James Version reads, <i>You will receive power after that the Holy Spirit is
come upon you.</i> The Greek reads, </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
. . <i>. But you-will-receive power, the Holy Spirit having-come on you, and
you-will-be . . . . </i>The tautology of the KJV, after-that has a longer
form of after, has been taken by modern readers to mean, <i>You will receive
power; after <u>that</u>-time, you-will-receive the Holy Spiri</i> [as in Acts
<b>2</b>:38, taken as non-miraculous]. Such a meaning would require an added
Greek word for <u>that</u> [probably </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>]
The argument was used against pentecostalism by saying, <i>You will receive
power and after that</i> [receiving of power] <i>the Holy Spirit will come on
you</i>; the inference was that the Holy Spirit was not the source of the
power; it was directly given by God in this instance. The case serves as an
example of the kind of thing English readers might imagine without guidance from
the Greek original.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> English
readers will find both <i>James, the brother of James</i> (KJV) and <i>James,
the son of James</i> (ASV, <i>etc</i>.). The difference is a translation
matter, not a manuscript variant. The Greek text simply reads Judas of James.
The word son or brother are added to clarify the shorthand expression in
the original.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
expression X of Y is used almost always for son of, when able to be
checked, although if context could clarify it, a writer might use the format to
indicate wife of, father of, brother of, or some other relationship. The
standard relationship, however, is son-to-father when this idiom appears.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The reason
translators like those of the King James Version (the New King James reads son
of) have thought it might mean brother of here is that there were two
prominent brothers in the Jerusalem church named Judas and James. They authored
the two New Testament letters by those names. But those brothers were
half-brothers of Jesus, as most New Testament scholars agree. The Judas and
James of Acts <b>1</b>:13 would surely not refer to these men since the next
verse mentions Jesus brothers separately as present in the upper room. There
would be no reason for mentioning them in <b>1</b>:14 after naming them in <b>1</b>:13.
Since <u>James</u> (Jacob) was a common Hebrew name, it is not surprising to
find it connected yet another time with people within, and related to, the
apostolic circle.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In the final
analysis, it probably does not affect the point about whether the apostles were
witnesses of Jesus resurrection. The witness role is stated within the context
of resurrection; consequently, the only issue is whether Peter means to <u>specify</u>
witnessing to Christs resurrection particularly or to bear general witness for
him, which <u>includes</u> his resurrection.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> There is a
change of person and number from repent to be baptized. Literally it is
translated, <i>Repent </i>[pl]<i>, and let each-one of-you be-baptized in the
name of Jesus Christ unto remission of your sins.</i> Consequently, the stress
grammatically falls more directly on the connection between baptizing and
remission than it does on repenting and remission.</span></p>

the Bible Says About Salvation</i><u>,</u> pp. 245-56.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
difference is that baptism under the second alternative takes place after a
person is saved, that is, has remission of sins.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The phrase with
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>occurs
with Johns repentance unto remission of sins (Mark <b>1</b>:4). It occurs as
well with the blood of Jesus Christ that was poured out unto remission of sin
(Matthew <b>26</b>:28). So the expected value of </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
something before that leads to something after. The reason for balking at that
value for baptism is a fear of works. So the idea has been to find some other
value for the act, a value like a subsequent outward act for a previous inward
grace, or baptism into the visible church, or as a testimony to other people, or
baptism at the time of (but not unto) remission of sins. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> That fear proves
to be unnecessary because works as contrary to salvation by faith is not <u>doing</u>
something but <u>producing</u> something. Baptism is not a cause of salvation
but part of a condition cluster for Gods giving salvation. Besides, it is an
interpersonal act, not a legal one. Its meaning is the point that we must
grasp. As Acts<b> 2</b>:38 puts it, in baptism we identify ourselves with
Jesuscommit ourselves to him, his purposes, and values, which are the same as
the Fathers. On the basis of our willingness to commit ourselves to Christ,
God <u>forgives sin</u>, that is, <u>considers us righteous</u> like the righteous
One we commit ourselves to. The saving takes place in the mind and will of God,
not produced by the human act or as the result of an external legal operation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> For practical
purposes it is important here not to use the common shorthand expression in
place of the full statement that Peter makes. Baptized . . . for remission
lends itself too easily to leaving out the most crucial part of the statement: <i>be
baptized <u>in the name of Jesus</u> unto remission of sins.</i> The act of
baptism commits us to Jesus Christ, and it is on the basis of our willingness
to the-identity-with-him/commit-ourselves-to-him that God considers us
righteous like him, which is the positive side of the negative side remission
of sins.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Be
saved from this crooked generation.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Though the
verb is imperative, it is passive. The statement does not address the connection
between what a person does and the result that comes. What you do (active) is
connected with being saved (passive); but beyond that, the passage does not
lend itself to whether salvation is active or passive or some kind of
combination in sequence. People do what God commands as conditions for Gods doing
the saving, but peoples doing those things does not save them in whole or in
part. The decisive juncture is divine pronouncement in an interpersonal
circumstance. Cp. looking at the brazen serpent as a condition for curing
snakebite (John<b> 3</b>:14-15). The act on the part of the offending party
only meets a condition for the other person to give the result. The condition
is what logic calls an occasional cause, but it does not itself contribute to
producing the result: looking on brazen serpents is not the way to cure
snakebite; it was only a condition God laid down to the Israelites for <u>his</u>
curing the snakebite. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> If the second
option is a non-restrictive clauseadding in the comma, then the statement
means all people will be restored. But no Old Testament passage predicts the
salvation of all people. Scripture is clear that not all will be saved; so we
must understand the ambiguous in light of the clear. So again, the unclear is
interpreted in light of the clear.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> They were
bringing their goods and distributing them as people had need. The verb is
imperfect rather than aorist. The imperfect implies that they were selling
things as need arose instead of getting rid of everything. This is not a
communistic situation where private property did not exist; it was an ongoing
program by which private property that did exist was dispensed with because of
the higher need of those who could not support themselves. This was a practical
process, not a theoretical system. </span></p>

were baptized in the name of Jesus <u>only</u>.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>They
were <u>only</u> baptized in the name of Jesus.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
Jesus-only reading is an English example of a misplaced only. In the
original, only appears at the front of the sentence, indicating that they had
just been baptized into the name of Jesus, evidently in contrast to also
receiving gifts of the Holy Spirit through the laying on of hands. The passage is
not in tension with the wording of the Great Commission, where baptism was <i>into
the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.</i> The trinity issue
lies behind recasting the wording in Acts<b> 8</b>:16 as Jesus <i>vs</i>. <i>Father,
Son, and Spirit.</i> Whatever we do with that issue, it does not find support
in this verse. The law of opposition puts baptism in contrast to receiving
gifts of the Spirit by the hands of Peter and John, not in contrast to being
baptized into the name of Father-Son-Spirit. Receiving the Spirit by the laying
on of the apostles hands was the reason the church in Jerusalem sent Peter and
John down to Samaria. So, what the apostles did is what stands in contrast to
only what had happened before: they had been baptized.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> See <i>What
the Bible Says About Salvation</i>, pp. 389-95.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The tense
here can be construed as progressive rather than characteristic. It is a
present tense inside an indirect discourse construction; in indirect discourse Greek
uses present to mean simultaneous with the main verb (or the same tense as
would have been used in the direct quotation). Using the passage to argue that
only the apostles could pass on miraculous take the verb as characteristic
action, meaning that this was the way the passing on of gifts always occurred.
But not only is that reconstruction unnecessary, it does not fit the context
very well: Simon was watching only what was happening in front of him at
Samaria. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The interest
in having only the apostles able to pass on gifts is for creating a scenario
that works against having supernatural gifts in the church throughout the
church age and today. When the apostles passed off the scene, there would be no
more passing on miraculous gifts, which eliminates modern manifestation. But, it
is better to test claims than to rely on unnecessary reconstructions of texts
to promote. The modern church is not at a disadvantage in this matter if
supernatural manifestation because we are called to exercise the same discernment
that first-century Christians had to exerciseas with evaluating men like Simon
the sorcerer from the city of Samaria (Acts <b>8</b>:9-13) and the seven sons
of Sceva (Acts <b>19</b>:14-17). If only apostles could pass on miraculous
gifts to third parties, how do we explain Ananias healing Sauls blindness in
Antioch (Acts<b> 9</b>:11-12; <b>22</b>:13). Besides, the proposed scenario
creates a mechanical process for equipping process and Holy Spirit operations.
Not having a lineage of impartation by manual imposition also eliminates pride
in tracing back ones roots to one apostle rather than anothersomething like
what the Corinthians were doing in choosing between leaders (1 Corinthians <b>1-4</b>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> It <u>is</u>
appropriate to ask why Philip himself did not pass on gifts if he could,
instead of the Jerusalem churchs sending down two apostles for that purpose. An
appropriate explanation is that sending apostles to Samaria showed that the
ages-old Jewish animosity toward Samaritans was no longer relevant to the
divine economy: the (a) <u>leaders</u> (apostles) of the new economy
demonstrated the full divine acceptance of Samaritans into Messiahs kingdom by
coming from (b) <u>Jerusalem</u>, the center of the Jewish system (John<b> 4</b>:20-26),
and giving (c) <u>supernatural gifts to the Samaritans themselves to exercise</u>.
That made their acceptance even more undeniable than just preaching to them and
baptizing them would have; the forthcoming supernatural manifestations were
something everyone could <u>see</u> as on Pentecost (Acts <b>2</b>) and later
at Caesarea (Acts <b>10</b>). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> So, (1) as
supernatural gifting showed the divine approval of the apostles among the <u>Jews</u>,
and (2) having the supernatural manifestations later come on the <u>Gentiles</u>
of Cornelius household (Acts <b>10</b>:44-48), so also (3) providing
supernatural manifestation through the <u>Samaritans</u> showed divine approval
of their entering into the Kingdom of God. Acts is tracing the expansion of the
gospel from (1) Jerusalem (<b>2</b>:1-47), to (2) Samaria (<b>8</b>:4-25), to
(3) the uttermost parts of the earth (<b>10</b>:1-48)as per <b>1</b>:8. That
pattern shows the essential steps in the full witness of Acts to the expansion
of Christianity from Jerusalem to Rome.</span></p>

12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>, the text says
that the voice was speaking in the Hebrew dialect (<b>26</b>:14). Hebrew could
mean classical Hebrew instead of the Aramaic the populace of Palestine used at
the time. Perhaps Pauls traveling companions did not know classical Hebrew.
They may have been from the Greek-speaking synagogue in Jerusalem that Paul and
Stephen were from (Acts <b>6</b>:9). However, in Jerusalem the word is used
evidently to refer to Aramaic, which is what Paul used in addressing the temple
mob (either that or the populace would have understood classical Hebrewif they
listened carefully). There was enough difference between Aramaic and Hebrew
that Ezra and Nehemiah read the law to the returning exiles and interpreted it

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (3)
became a believer.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The text
should not be used to show that people receive the Spirit when they believe <i>vs.</i>
when they are baptized. The believing and being baptized occur together when a
person accepts Jesus as the Messiah. There should be no fear that baptism is,
somehow, a work and must be separated from salvation; it is an expression of
faith and is therefore an act of faith by the law of the harvest. A result
has the character of what produces it. It is an act of identification with
Christ; the forgiveness of sins arises out of that identity with him: (a)
baptized into Christ and (b) receiving forgiveness of sins (Acts<b> 2</b>:38). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Hebraism/hendiadys</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

speaking in languages and prophesying a composite act or two separate acts? See
comments on <b>10</b>:46 and 1 Timothy <b>2</b>:11 for the other examples in
question.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The aorist
participle is basically non-temporal; consequently, <i>having called on his
name</i> is not a natural rendering. See A. T. Robertson, <i>Grammar of the
Greek New Testament</i>, 1112-13; Dana &amp; Mantey, <i>Manual Grammar</i>,
178; Blass/Debrunner, <i>A Greek Grammar of the New Testament and Other Early
Christian Literature</i>, pp. 174-75.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> As so often
in these texts that involve baptism, the driving force behind discussions is
the fear of works in salvation by faith as if baptism were a work. It is an act
of faith for formally identifying with Christ; it does not <u>produce</u> the
result (forgiveness), which is what a work is.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The first
option does not fit the context well. Does righteousness of God contrast with
righteousness of the Law, righteousness of ones own, self-righteousness? The

where the righteousness derives from an interpersonal system and comes from
having it reckoned on us by another Person.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Evidently, <i>righteousness
of God</i> could come both in a law context and outside a law context.
Descriptive or possessive genitive could fit this requirement.</span></p>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>].
All these have objective genitives on the phrase in question. The decision on
objective<i> vs</i>. subjective genitive must be decided on contextual
considerations. See elsewhere in these notes for that determination. The
principal points are (1) the Habakkuk <b>2</b>:4 context for Romans and
Galatians. (2) In <b>10</b>:38 the Hebrew writer uses the Habakkuk reference in
a way that makes the faith/trust something the righteous one has, the typical
follower of God. (3) The line of thought traces from Habakkuk on back to
Genesis<b> 15</b>:6, which cites the faith/trust <u>Abraham</u> had as a basis
for Gods reckoning him righteous. (4) That assemblage of points in Romans and
Galatians pertains to salvation by the faith of people <i>vs</i>. works, not
the faithfulness of the Messiah. Note the law of opposition.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The King
James wording leaves the meaning unclear since <u>come</u> is both the present
and past participle of the verb to come, as if it means have sinned and
have come. A reader does not know whether to take <u>come</u> as parallel to <u>have
sinned</u> or as parallel to <u>sinned</u> with <u>have</u> serving as the
auxiliary to both verbs. The second verb is present tense in the Greek, so the
passage means that everyone has sinned, and they do so now as well.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) A third
way is to take the first verb as a gnomic aorist: <i>For all sin and fall
short . . . . </i>When combined with another verb in the present, we would not
expect an aorist to have a gnomic force.</span></p>

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2)
because-of whom all sinned</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In whom is
then taken to mean in Adam, and from that derives the notion of federal guilt:
the whole race is guilty because Adam, who sinned, was the race; so the guilt
adheres to all people.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> See <i>What
the Bible Says About Salvation</i>, pp. 26ff.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Romans 5:12</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> translation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mean
all sinned or all have sinned? In Romans<b> 3</b>:23 this same form must be
understood as referring to all men over a long period of time. Aorist does not
mean one-time act <i>vs</i>. ongoing process. An aorist can refer to what has
been a recurring reality as a matter of fact because the aorist refers to any
action as a <u>fact</u> contemplated in the mind rather than as a <u>process</u>
contemplated in the mind. The distinction between aorist and imperfect or
perfect is the way the speaker is thinking about it, not the way the action
objectively is (note <b>16</b>:2: </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>).
The point of the </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>in
<b>5</b>:12 is not that as an aorist it refers to Adams one-time <u>act</u> of
sinin which all men are <u>legally</u> implicated by being his <u>physical</u>
descendants. So far in Romans, Pauls whole point has been that soteriology is
not figured in legal termsit is not driven by legal principles; it is figured
in terms of the person who is acting. Anyway, to show Gods manner of viewing
guilt, even the Law forbade punishing children for parents sins (Deuteronomy <b>24</b>:6).
The righteousness of the righteous is on themselves (Ezekiel <b>18</b>:20). The
<u>all sinned</u> of <b>3</b>:23 is the same as the <u>all sinned</u> in <b>5</b>:12.
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> 1 Timothy <b>6</b>:16
says <i>whom no-one of-men saw/has-seen</i> [</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>]
<i>or can see.</i> The long historical process of not seeing God is referred
to as a <u>fact</u>; that is, the linear reality is referred to as a punctiliar
fact. 1 Timothy <b>6</b>:21 illustrates the same idiom: <i>erred concerning
the faith.</i> This is not some specific occasion or act but an ongoing
occurrence of false conviction.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Finally, it
is possible to take the verb here as a gnomic aorist, which provides another
way of hearing the verb as not referring to Adams original sin act.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Participles
can cover for time, means, manner, cause, condition, concession, attendant
circumstance, purpose, result, co-ordinate circumstance. So they do not specify
by form how the author means them; but they are valuable for raising
possibilities a reader might not otherwise think of. Strictly speaking, the
author does not mean any of the possibilities list here; his speaking vaguely
except insofar as the nature of the case and context shape his comment.</span></p>

the calling of Israel. There are cases where God does withdraw gifts and
calling: Saul as king over Israel, Judas as an apostle of Jesus Christ,
Samsons supernatural strength. That happens when there is an implied condition
for continued fulfillment. Note Jesus parable in Luke <b>20</b>:16. </span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
accompanying imagery is that of a temple. The question, then, is whether the

or individual stones of the templeor the temple corresponds to the body of the
individual Christian. Many interpreters see the building up of the temple as
the improving life quality of the individual believer, yet Paul began this
section with the notion of laying a foundation in the missionary enterprise.
The building up of the building seems, therefore, more appropriately to be the
adding of lives to the foundation. Each person becomes a living stone in the
building (cp. 1 Peter <b>2</b>:5).</span></p>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
is present tense. On the principle that present imperative means continuing to
do what is already being done, the very opposite would be said for correcting
some who were wanting to move away from sexual relations because of bringing
into their Christian conversion certain assumptions from pagan dualistic
sources. Otherwise, the import would be more that marriage provides for natural
sexual desires and so avoids fornication. If the previous idea were Pauls
intent, the matter of providing against fornication would be foreign, because
the same sensitivities that would direct against sexual relations in marriage
would direct against fornication too. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

unbelieving husband/wife is-set-apart in the wife/husband, otherwise your
children would be illegitimate, but now they are legitimate.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
sanctification is not a tendential notion because the verb is not a present (or
imperfect) tense; that is, it does not mean that the husband or wife tends to
make the spouse holy by his/her influence, an otherwise conceivable notion. The
perfect tense means sanctification is already the case while the spouse is an
unbeliever.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
un/clean-ness of the children evidently has to do with their being considered
legitimate. Marriage is a feature of humanity, not a feature of the church;
marriage exists outside the church. The partners are set apart to each other
in the eyes of society. A comparable use of the </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>-
root occurs in the Annunciation when the angel tells Mary that <i>the begotten
holy-(</i>thing/child/baby) <i>will be called the Son of God.</i> The implied
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>or

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
neuter.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Paul uses the
perfect passive here. Especially in the perfect passive participle, stress
falls on the resultant condition more than on the originating act, whether a person
was put into that condition by another or by himself. Cp. fit for destruction
in Romans and filled/full of the fruit of righteousness in Philippians <b>1</b>:11.
Occasionally a motorist sees a closed sign at the beginning of a new road;
similarly, loosed can mean an unattached person who has never been attached
in marriage.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

point, Paul is talking about needing to be married or needing to be single in
the Lord. He is not talking about divorce and remarriage. That could be a
different issue. It is not wise to apply an authors wording to matters he is
not addressing.</span></p>

a small s.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In favor of <i>giving

burning under Neros persecution in Rome later, it could conceivably mean that
such an act of martyrdom would not lead to salvation if Paul was not a loving
person. Exaggeration for emphasis has a place in this context by any approach.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Supposedly
the neuter article with a substantive adjective refers to an abstraction rather
than to something concrete. Therefore, the statement could not be a reference
to a particular <u>thing</u> like the canon or an event like the second coming.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> However, Paul
is speaking in a vivid future condition about a set of abstractions. When the
perfect comes, what is partial will be done away. Partialness is an
abstraction okay, but Paul may have in mind a concrete thing that exemplifies
the abstraction: something like the event of the second coming or the situation
of this life <i>vs</i>. the next.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> An
anti-pentecostal argument is also attempted by saying that since the perfect
is neuter it cannot refer to Christ at his second coming. It would not, of
course, refer to Christ, but to the situation involved at his coming. It would
not refer to him but to the event or situation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Instead of
referring to the <u>canon</u> or <u>the second coming</u>, </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
refers to something Paul can be in both conditions of; hence, the next life<b>
13</b>:12). Love abides now and in eternity, but speaking in languages is a
secondary matter associated with this life only.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Now
I-am-willing-for you all to speak in languages, but more that you may
prophesy.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
translation does not have Paul urging or pushing for every one of the
Corinthians to speak in languages. That fits with <b>12</b>:30, which implies
that by design not all in fact speak in languages.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>can
refer to <u>wanting</u> or <u>desiring</u> to do what originates in the person
himself. It can also refer to <u>being willing</u> to do what originates in
someone else. In the Corinthians situation, Paul means that he is <u>willing</u>
even for every one of them to speak in languages as long as it becomes prophecy
in the process, that is, as long as it is translated. He said earlier (<b>12</b>:30)
that not all speak in languages. His comment then is hyperbole for emphasis or
as a concession for arguments sake, which he makes so they do not
misunderstand him as forbidding speaking in languages itself rather than
forbidding the misuse of it. Paul was passively willing to let even all of them
speak in languages; he was not positively urging them to do so.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>And

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>And
greater is the one prophesying than the one speaking in languages, except
(someone) interpret.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The question
here is whether the one who speaks in languages also does the prophesying. <i>Except
he interprets</i> may mean, not that he has also the gift of interpretation,
but that he is explaining the concepts, which he knows at the general level. The
gift of interpretation would be for interpreting some elses speaking in
languages. Praying to interpret ones own speaking in languages (<b>14:</b>1-3)
would presumably be so he could express cogently in his own language the
presentation he just spoke in a language. In <b>14</b>:2 the apostle must mean
that the one who speaks in a language does not understand at the word-for-word
level. See on this site <i>Notes for Gifts of the Spirit</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> As far as
grammar goes, the question may be asked whether Greek uses the third singular
or plural verb without the indefinite pronoun in cases of unspecified subject,
which is what the second translation above assumes. Luke <b>12</b>:20 has a
third person plural verb without an expressed subject, but it is evidently in
reference to angels that he is speaking. Note also Matthew <b>9</b>:17<sup>3</sup>;

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The second translation is
offered in defense of sabbatarianism. The difficulty is that the word <u>first</u>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>because
it is in the wrong gender. One would have to be neuter to modify the implied
word </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(part)the
first part of the sabbath day. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Furthermore,
we would expect to find the word </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>as
the modifying element in circumstances that means the first of some set. The
first part of the sabbath would have to be after dark on Friday evening
because Jewish days began a sundown in Jewish reckoning. As to the facts, Acts <b>20</b>:7-12
did happen in the evening because Paul discoursed to the Christians in Troas
till the next morning. Since Paul and his fellow travelers left the next day,
they either did not observe the Sabbath, or Luke is using Roman time reckoning
in this event; otherwise, the next morning would have been on the Sabbath, as
would their subsequent traveling. Since Acts <b>2</b>:15and probably <b>3</b>:1is
Jewish time, Paul and his companions disregarded the Sabbath laws, being in a
Gentile territory (?). All the other hour references in Acts fit with Jewish
timing: <b>10</b>:3, 9, 30; <b>23</b>:23.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
is a case of metonymy where the seventh day of the week comes to serve as the
label for the week.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) This is a
gnomic aorist: <i>You are cut off from Christ . . . you have fallen from
grace.</i> You cannot add Christ to the law like the Judaizers are attempting
to do; you fall from grace when you do that.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A gnomic
aorist would state the principle that law and Christ are mutually exclusive
systems. A person must leave the one in adopting the other as total systems.
These peoples actual condition in the eyes of God can be a separate matter
from a statement about the nature of the law and grace systems in theory.
James, the brother of the Lord, tells Paul that thousands of Jews in the
homeland are zealous for the Law, and he does so without hinting that they are
all lost (Acts <b>21</b>:20). And, Paul goes along with James suggestion that
he take a vow with four Jewish Christians, an agreement that ended up getting
him arrested for two years in Caesarea, sailing the treacherous trip to Rome,
and spending two more years there in house arrest.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Taking </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>to
mean the non-fleshly, the transcendent, the spiritual makes the clearest sense
in cases where it contrasts with </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Other contexts that involve that contrast are John <b>3</b>:3-8; Romans<b> 8</b>:1-17,
and 1 Timothy<b> 3</b>:16. The preferred interpretation appeals to the law of
opposition in hermeneutics; statements mean most clearly what they are set in
contrast to.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In the first
instance, the translation assumes an epistolary aorist and Paul has in mind the
present sentence, not necessarily the previous part of the book (cp. 1
Corinthians <b>16</b>:21; Colossians <b>4</b>:8; 2 Thessalonians <b>3</b>:17). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
option regards it, not as an epistolary aorist, but as past tense in reference
to the previous part of the letter. The difference is a contrast between the
readers time viewpoint <i>vs</i>. the writers time viewpoint or a contrast
between the time of writing <b>6</b>:11 and the time of writing the previous
part of the letter.</span></p>

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>means
large as to size, not as to number. Paul is not talking about how many letters (of
the alphabet) he has written, hence, how long a letter he has written; but the
size of the letters he used as he wrote. That fact has suggested that Pauls
eyesight was bad, something associated with 2 Corinthians<b> 12</b>:7-9 under
the expression thorn in the flesh.</span></p>
