<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (3) <i> . .
. and that [salvation] (is) not of yourselves</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Since the
previous part of the sentence contains three ideas, the English is ambiguous as
to the antecedent of that. In the Greek, however, two of those antecedents
are eliminated because they are the wrong gender. That is neuter, and so
cannot refer specifically to grace or faith because they are feminine gender. So
that refers to salvation as the abstract idea in the verb. It would not
likely be the whole thingsalvation by faithbecause to say it is not of you
would be a truism inasmuch as grace is obviously Gods act.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> An
acquaintance of mine wanted to argue that faith is not an act here and so he
wanted to understand it on the analogy of Romans <b>1</b>:5; Ephesians <b>4</b>:13;
Colossians <b>1</b>:23; Titus <b>1</b>:4; Jude 3. That makes the faith a
system of understanding (the gospel) rather than a principle of relationship
(kind of thing). The idea hangs on whether faith is an act. It is the <u>name</u>
of an act, though.</span></p>

1 Peter <b><i>2</i></b>:25; 1 Peter <b>1</b>:10. <u>Pastor</u> and <u>teacher</u>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>;</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Ephesians 5:21</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> editorial
question</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does <i>submit
yourselves to one another out of respect for Christ</i> belong with the
preceding or succeeding context?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The UBS Greek
text of the New Testament puts it with the preceding material in the third
edition, but with the succeeding context in the third edition
(corrected)likewise the 5<sup>th</sup> <sup>ed rev</sup>. Grammatically the
participle submitting parallels earlier participles in the preceding two
versesparticiples that modify the subject of the finite verb in <b>5</b>:18.
Conceivably a free-standing participle can give a command; but clear cases of
that usage are infrequent in the New Testament: Mark<b> 5</b>:23; Romans <b>12</b>:9<sup>2</sup>,
10?, 11?, 12<sup>3</sup>?, 13<sup>2</sup>?, 17<sup>2</sup>?, 18, 19; <b>13</b>:11;
1 Corinthians<b> 8</b>:24; Ephesians <b>5</b>:21?; Titus <b>2</b>:7; 1 Peter<b>
2</b>:18; <b>3</b>:1. Even so, there is no grammatical call for invoking that
usage in Ephesians <b>5</b>:21 because of the parallel between submitting and
the preceding participles of <b>5</b>:19-20. Grammatically, then, submitting connects
with the preceding material.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Conceptually,
of course, <b>5</b>:18-21 forms a natural context for the household instruction
in <b>5</b>:22-<b>6</b>:9; but it forms a conceptual setting for the whole unit
of household instruction, not just for the marriage section (21-33). Those who
are particularly interested in getting away from a hierarchical element in
marriage want to connect the sentence with what follows and with only the
marriage part of it. That seems to them to establish an egalitarian arrangement
for the home since they understand one another as full individual reciprocation
(see below).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> However,
making that connection grammatically and conceptually does not de-structure the
home. First, (a) structure and interpersonalism are compatible. Structure adds
to specialized interpersonal situations like marriage, the church, parenting
without pre-empting it or setting it aside. Christs being head of the church
does not conflict with his love for the church; structure does not conflict
with interpersonalism; so we do not have to get rid of order to maintain
interpersonalism. This same issue Paul and other writers speak of elsewhere,
encouraging people in congregations to obey them that have the rule over them
in the church (Hebrews<b> 13</b>:17,<i> etc</i>.).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Second, (b)
in this passage Pauls obvious point is the very opposite of
de-structuralismthat is, anarchy in the technical sense. That should be clear
from his admonition to children to obey their parents, and the parenting
section is part of this same unit on household operation. Paul makes a
concerted effort to compare his teaching on marriage with Christs relationship
to the church. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Not only does
<b>5</b>:21 serve to introduce the whole household teaching section, it comes
out of a much broader context. The household teaching provides prime examples
of a more orderly applicable principle.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Ephesians 5:21</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>Submit
yourselves to one another.</i> [reciprocal between individuals]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Submission in
this sense could cover two sub-formats, one format in which (a) each does the
same thing to the other and another format in which (b) one submits to the
other in respect to some things while the other submits to the first in other
things.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
10.0pt;margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%'>&nbsp;</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
10.0pt;margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%'>  I
 You</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
10.0pt;margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Submit
yourselves to one another.</i> [one-directional within a group]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
10.0pt;margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%'>  
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Christ</span></p>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%'>   X</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
10.0pt;margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%'>  X
X</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
10.0pt;margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Interpreters
have been trying to handle Ephesians <b>5</b>:21 in the first format ever since
the womens rights issue became part of American cultural concern in the 1970s.
In so doing, their goal has been to remove any essential distinctiveness of the
husband-to-wife <i>vs.</i> wife-to-husband relationship. We can sympathize with
Christians desire not to create more differences between the general culture
(the world) and the church than is necessary so as not to create unnecessary
hurdles for accepting the Christian faith and the truthfulness of the Bible. We
also sympathize with the concern to find a way of counteracting the abuse of
male domination, chauvinism, and the attitude of condescension toward wives and
women. In fact, Paul seems to have that very concern in this section of
Ephesians because his commands to husbands and wives address the faults that
each most often has. He commands husbands to <u>love</u> their wives (but not
vice versa here) because husbands most frequent sin is running over their
wives. He commands wives to <u>respect</u> their husbands (but not <i>vice
versa</i> here or anywhere) because wives most frequent sin is trying to
compete with their husbands.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The first
understanding of the reciprocal pronoun ends up meaning a purely interpersonal
manner of operation between (a) husbands and wives, (b parents and children,
and (c) masters and slaves. There is a sense in which parents can submit to
their childrenby not discouraging them (Colossians <b>3</b>:21). Masters can
submit to slavesby not being hard on them (Ephesians <b>6</b>:9). Husbands
can submit to their wivesin giving themselves for their spouses (Ephesians <b>5</b>:25).
Christ submitted to the church by giving himself for it (Ephesians <b>5</b>:25).
In all three cases, we could say that attitudinally <u>both</u> sides of the
relationship submit to one another. <i>Let each person consider the other
better than himself.</i> While this last idea is true and should be stressed,
it should be derived from Philippians <b>2</b>:3-4 or perhaps Galatians <b>6</b>:1-5,
not from Ephesians <b>5</b>:21. Obviously, the first format is appropriate in
any circumstance, but in this context a person would not expect Paul to be
referring to such an arrangement. In fact, his point seems to be the very
opposite. He is concerned to prevent the disorder that comes when no one has final
responsibility and when others do not respect the appointed persons
responsibility. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (a) If the
reader is to consider <b>5</b>:21 an introduction to the succeeding context,
then it should be interpreted as applying to the whole section on household
teaching. If so, the second arrangement would have parents submitting to their
children (<b>6</b>:1-4), masters submitting to their slaves (<b>6</b>:5-9), and
Christ submitting to his church (<b>5</b>:25-32) in the same sense that
children, slaves, and Christians are to submit parents, masters, and Christ.
While it is possible for masters, husband, and Christ to submit, they do not
do so in the same sense that slaves, wives, and children submit.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Furthermore,
(b) the mutual submission mentality does not negate one-directional submission
in order. One has to do with attitude while the other has to do with authority
as a reinforcement of responsibility. There is nothing about authority that
means proper attitude is forfeit. Authority derives from responsibility, which
in turn derives from purpose. In the final analysis, the point of authority
here is the very opposite of the fears that people have of it. The concern is
to assign responsibility for the home, which puts the onus on the husband
rather than make him someone who can act as he pleases without recourse from
the other person. As Paul tells masters to remember that they have a Master in
heaven (Ephesians <b>6</b>:9; Colossians <b>4</b>:1), so also husbands are
under the headship of Christ, whom they are to respect (Ephesians <b>5</b>:21;
1 Corinthians <b>11</b>:3).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
10.0pt;margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%'> <img width=370 height=114 id="Picture 10"
src="/cir-library/images/essays/greek-helps-in-new-testament-interpretation/image001.png"
alt="A diagram of a diagram of a diagram&#10;&#10;Description automatically generated"></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
10.0pt;margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(c) There are texts where
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>does
not mean the kind of reciprocality that is in format #1 above. The clearest
example is Revelation<b> 6</b>:4, <i> . . . that they should kill one
another. </i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Galatians <b>5</b>:15
speaks of devouring one another.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In Acts <b>19</b>:34
the mayor of Ephesus tells the mob that if Demetrius and his craftsmen have a
case against some, <i>Let them accuse one another.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Matthew<b> 24</b>:10
talks about betraying one another.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In 1
Corinthians <b>6</b>:7; Paul complains that the Corinthians are having lawsuits
with one another. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In 1
Thessalonians <b>4</b>:18 Paul tells his readers to comfort one another. In
most circumstances, one person is hurting, and another comforts him; they are
not usually both hurting and in need of comfort.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Luke <b>12</b>:1
speaks of the multitudes treading on one another. The situation does not
picture people stepping on one anothers feet in a strictly reciprocal way. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> There are
some occasions like Luke <b>8</b>:25 where people in a crowd ask one another, <i>Who
then is this, that even the wind and water obey him is commands?</i> Other
cases of speaking to one another are Luke <b>7</b>:32; <b>24</b>:32; John<b> 4</b>:32;
<b>19</b>:24; (Acts <b>2</b>:7<sup>ms</sup>).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Acts <b>7</b>:26-27
may be another example depending on the particulars in the event<i>: Sirs, you
are brothers. Why do you wrong one to another</i> (cp. Luke <b>7</b>:32).
Stephen notes in his speech before the Sanhedrin, <i>Why do you mistreat one
another.</i> <i>And the one who was mistreating the neighbor thrust him
aside.</i> The mistreating was actually one-directional, but </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
used because two sides were involved (Acts <b>7</b>:26-27 &lt; Exodus<b> 2</b>:13).
(Two other reciprocal expression in Greek are </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>and
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> James <b>5</b>:16
may be another example of one-directional use of </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
because the text has been talking about a situation where people are to call
the elders to heal a man. The healed mans confession rather than the elders
confession also may be the intended point, although in parallel to confession
is prayer for one another. Of course, the prayer for one another may be the
prayer of the elders for the sick man as the sick mans confession is to the
elders.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> 1 Corinthians
<b>7</b>:5 is a one-another passage that deals with marriage: defraud one
another. Defrauding could happen in both directions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Whether to
take the first or second format of reciprocation depends on the situation. In
the case of domestic relations, order is not set aside.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Such a
comment misses the point about the middle voice. By the nature of the case, in
an intransitive usage, submitting is something the person does who has lower rank.
It is significant that Paul addresses the submitting one, not that having
decided to address the submitting one, he uses the middle voice. The verb is
deponent in the New Testament; hence, it is not used with a active-voice value.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) Why is </span><span

because its antecedent is </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (b)
because its gender is attracted to the predicate nominative </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (c)

12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

John <b>1</b>:41, <u>42</u>; <b>9</b>:7; Acts<b> 4</b>:36; Ephesians <b>5</b>:5;
Colossians <b>1</b>:24; <b><u>3</u></b><u>:14</u>; 2 Thessalonians <b>3</b>:17;
Hebrews<b> 7</b>:2; Revelation <b>20</b>:2, 12; <b>21</b>:17. See Moulton &amp;
Geden. <i>Concordance of the Greek New Testament </i>(5<sup>th ed</sup>), pp.
707-8.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Colossians
<b>3</b>:14 has a feminine antecedent, so the force is not that is, and </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> the
predicate is not neuter: <i>Above all these things, put on love, which is the</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> perfect
bond. </span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'>Mark <b>15</b>:42 has a feminine antecedent, but a
neuter predicate</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> nominative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

Spirit (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;

12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>): nearest

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>): phrase head
(note Revelation <b>2</b>:7; <b>14</b>:10; James <b>1</b>:12b)</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (b)

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (c)
genitive of source: the sword that comes from the Spirit</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (d)
descriptive genitive: spiritual sword = Gods sword</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> These
variables create the following three sets of syntactical relationships</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The third
translation does not strike us as natural in one way of reading it since the
Spirit <u>is</u> a person, not a message. To say that the Spirit is the word of
God would have to mean that the Spirit corresponds to the word; the word is the
functional equivalent of the Spirit. In that sense the statement is used in the
service of claiming that the only contemporary operation of the Spirit is
through the word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> If the
genitive on </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is
appositive (format #1), the final meaning becomes the same as format #3, where
there is no attraction of gender on which.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <u>Attraction
of gender</u> means that the relative pronoun takes the gender of the predicate
nominative within its own clause rather than the gender of the antecedent.
(Such attraction, of course, can only occur in clauses with linking verbs.)
There are some examples of attraction of gender in the New Testamentmost with
the that is kind of expression: Mark<b> 15</b>:16; Galatians <b>3</b>:16;
Ephesians [<b>1</b>:14]; <b>6</b>:17?; 1 Timothy <b>3</b>:15; 1 John<b> 2</b>:8;
Revelation<b> 4</b>:5. That is (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
occurs several times as a set expression aside from gender or number: Acts <b>16</b>:12;
1 Corinthians <b>3</b>:17; Ephesians [<b>1</b>:14]; <b>3</b>:13; <b><u>5</u></b><u>:5</u>;
Philippians <b>1</b>:28. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> We do not
have to invoke <u>attraction of gender</u> as a way to avoid making Spirit
the antecedent or predicate nominative. Note especially Matthew <b>27</b>:33
and Ephesians <b>5</b>:5. The notion of operating only through the word amounts
to operating conceptually. It raises the question about how a person can stop
arguing likewise against answered prayer. Besides, Paul is addressing the
situation in his own day. If his comments eliminate miraculous manifestation,
they eliminate miraculous manifestation in his own day. We know from the New
Testament records that such was not the case; so the interpretation needs to be
set aside. See likewise below.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The question
about <u>appositive genitive</u> <i>vs</i>. genitive of source, description, or
possession is somewhat unclear. If we go on the basis of parallelism, of the
Spirit could be appositional genitive. Spiritual sword makes sense as well.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> loins
gird with truth</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> breastplate of
righteousness</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> feet
shod with the
preparation of the gospel of </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> peace</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> shield of
faith</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> helmet of
salvation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> sword of
the S/spirit</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The breastplate <u>is</u>
righteousness; the shield <u>is</u> faith; the helmet <u>is</u> salvation; so
sword <u>is</u> the word of God. A person could, however, conceive of the
conceptual parallelism as being with word rather than Spirit. The
parallelism with previous entries lies with word (</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>),
not spirit anyway. Consequently, the appositional genitives in the previous
armor parts do not dictate appositional genitive on <u>Spirit</u>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Paul makes a
balanced construction between sword of the Spirit and word of God as these
two phrases stand on each side of which is. It makes best sense because of
this parallelism <u>within</u> the entry (rather than <u>between</u> entries)
to take both ofs in the same sense. Since word <u>of</u> God is not
appositional, neither is sword <u>of</u> the Spirit. Rather, they both are
possessive, descriptive, or source genitives.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> If this is
genitive of source, possession, or description, then the idea is that the word
of God is a sword we can use much as Jesus did in the temptation accounts
(Matthew <b>4</b>:1-11; Luke <b>4</b>:1-13). See also Hebrews <b>4</b>:12 and 2
Timothy<b> 3</b>:16-17. It may be observed that sword of the Spirit is the first
<u>offensive</u> piece of warfare equipment in this text. The previous pieces
of armor serve <u>defensive</u> roles. If it is offensive, then we do not
expect of to be appositive genitive, but possessive, source, or descriptive
genitive because a sword is something someone uses. Therefore, what a sword is
affects how <i><u>Spirit</u></i> connects with it. It is something offensively
used by an agent; therefore, it is not appositive genitive.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Aside from
grammatical considerations, it is not likely that Paul would mean by <u>this
text</u> that the Holy Spirit operates only through the word. The reason for
wanting to make that claim is so that in the modern setting, Christians can automatically
discount claims of supernatural manifestation or special revelation. But (a)
there is no denying that such experiences were occurring when Paul wrote. He
would not then be saying that the Holy Spirit operates only through the message
because that was not the case at the time. The Spirit was operating in
miraculous manifestation, and not much of the written message existed yet. If
word is broadened beyond written word to mean conceptual statement, then the
argument is lost against current revelation and special divine guidance. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) Even if
we were to say that the Spirit is the sword, it would hardly prove that there
is a one-for-one correlation with the <u>written</u> word. The Spirit is now
Gods means of communicating with his people. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Furthermore,
(c) to say that the Spirit is/correlates with the word does not necessarily
prove that the Spirit is/correlates <u>only</u> with the word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Finally, (d)
we must ask again how a person can be consistent in using this text to argue
against modern-day miraculous manifestation without arguing against answered
prayer as well and against miraculous manifestation in the first century. What
proves too much does not prove what it seems to prove.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Strictly
speaking, the passage does not say every knee will bow, <i>etc. </i>The
subjunctive mood appears in a purpose clause; apparently Pauls point is that
God exalted Christ with the intent that every knee would bow,<i> etc</i>. So
the reference does not necessarily address universalism. The second verb after </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
varies between subjunctive and future indicative with about equal manuscript
support. If the future indicative is correct, then it predicts that everyone <u>will</u>
confess that he is Lord at least under duresswhen it is too late to make a
difference (?).</span></p>

"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) Partitive genitive would mean that
Jesus was part of all creation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Descriptive genitive would have the
force of firstborn over all creatin.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The passage
is appealed to for arguing that Jesus was the first created being, hence,
partitive genitive. If partitive genitive, then it is more natural also to
translate the whole phrase <i>firstborn of every creature/created-thing.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> On the other
hand, the presence of all with creation would not be so likely, it would
seem, as it would be if the meaning were firstborn over all creation. In
general, the genitive case ties one noun to another grammatically. About all it
shows is that the referents of the nouns belong together. How they are
associated depends on context and the nature of the referents. The partitive
genitive firstborn from the dead in <b>1</b>:18 has </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
but this may also be out-of.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Preferences
for a particular interpretation comes from matters external to the text under
consideration. In this case the preference for partitive genitive is driven by
the desire to promote a particular view of the trinity.</span></p>

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>might
be construed as even</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A related
consideration is what know means. Does it mean know about or be in
relationship to? Not knowing may amount to not being obedient.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> There are
articles on the front of both descriptions, a fact that tends to picture them
as two groups. If we combine that with know, we might get to the belief that
the unevangelized are lost. A counter consideration can be that they are not in
relationship to him although they have heard the gospel. But there is no way to
tell which option makes sense, given the rest of the Christian system. The fate
of the unevangelized cannot be determined by this verse because it may be an
example of synonymous parallelism. So any conclusion regarding the state of the
unevangelized must come from systematic theological considerations derived from
elsewhere. Options people have proposed include (a) sliding-scale judgment
based on conscience wherein it has properly led each person (cp. Romans <b>2</b>:11-16);
(b) annihilation of the unevangelized, (c) salvation option after death (2
Peter <b>3</b>:18-20;<b> 4</b>:1-6?). It is best to leave the matter
unresolved, and to be satisfied with using sanctified imagination for constructing
options that justify God without committing to any of them. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The question
comes mainly from a general concern for consistency in Christian teaching:
would a loving God send people to hell for not doing or believing what they had
no way to know to do? An alternate way of judging the 99% of humanity over all
the time in history makes the best sense.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Compare the
problem in John <b>3</b>:5. </span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The one
article that could fit over God and Lord according to Sharps rule. The
our in this circumstance probably modifies both nouns though expressed just
once. Sharps rule does not have to mean that two nouns under the same article
are two ways of referring to the same thing; they may be combined this way
because, though different, they form a unit. The situation can be like an
English statement, <i>The father and mother came into the hospital.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

savior and Jesus our hope </i>separates the God and Jesus equation that would
otherwise be implied by Sharps rule as in this 2 Thessalonians text.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) Are <u>heart</u>,
<u>conscience</u>, and <u>faith</u> parallel to love as a series of predicate
nominatives?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Are <u>heart</u>,
<u>conscience</u>, and <u>faith</u> common objects of out-of?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Since heart,
conscience, and faith are genitive rather than nominative, they are three
objects of out-of. Love comes out of these three: <i>the end of the charge
is out of a pure heart, good conscience, and unfeigned faith.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1 Timothy 1:13</span></b><span

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Did Paul do
what he did ignorantly in <u>un</u>belief or <u>dis</u>belief (</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)?
Alpha-privative words can be either negative or neutral.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The answer
cannot come from grammar or vocabulary, but from the record in Acts, it seems
that Paul did it in <u>dis</u>belief.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> It has been

font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>underscores
the content imparted in teaching, while </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>refers
to the teaching role. Supposedly relevant texts are 1 Corinthians <b>4</b>:17;
Ephesians<b> 4</b>:21; Colossians <b>1</b>:28;<b> 2</b>:7; and 1 Timothy<b> 6</b>:2.
Consequently, Paul did not want them teaching <i>what they were teaching</i>;
they were not learning first before they taught, and so they were teaching
heresies. That sounds like an awful lot to get out of one word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(1) Does </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mean
to usurp, so that it is okay if men let her?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(2) Does </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mean
to domineer, so that she might exercise authority as long as she does not do
it in a domineering manner? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(3) Does </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mean
to exercise authority, so that it is not appropriate for a woman to be
positioned above a man in the home or in the church? </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>For
a discussion of these points, see Scot Bartchy in Power, Submission, and
Sexual Identity Among the Early Christians, <i>Essays on New Testament
Christianity</i>, pp. 71-74.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1 Timothy 2:12</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>  vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Does
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mean
husband or man? Husband would fit with the Adam-Eve example Paul cites next,
but it could also fit the larger church context beyond the home.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>The
associations with upcoming directives about elders put these closing verses of
chapter <b>2</b> in connection with the larger church setting. Paul would not
have any say in how a husband and wife related on day-by-day items in the
home; of what point, then, would it be for him to say, <i>I do not allow a
woman . . . .</i>? The preceding verse likewise pictures a public setting (<b>2</b>:8-11),
and <b>2</b>:8 uses men in a generic sense parallel to women in <b>2</b>:9.
One claim is that when there is a shift from plural to singular, the meaning
normally becomes husband and wife (as in German?). Another point here is
that if a woman should not do something like exercise authority over her own
husband, she should all the more not do it over someone elses husband as would
be the case in a public, mixed setting, especially if such teaching was
perceived as authoritative. Another claim is that </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
means to act with independent jurisdiction as a close synonym. Could the
meaning here then be that Paul did not allow women to act with jurisdiction
independent of their husbands? So there are cultural considerations involved that
reinforce Pauls comment I do not allow. Which could be adjusted if some
cultural components do not apply everywhere for or at later times.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>As
regards teach and exercise authority, we may ask whether it is a feature of
Semitic idiom to use two verbs for indicating one composite action made up of
two parts conjointly (hendiadys) as in an adverb-adjective composite. Exodus <b>33</b>:20
says, <i>No one can see me and live. Does that mean no one can see me while
alive.</i> Can the same question apply to Acts<b> 10</b>:46; <b>19</b>:6;
Revelation<b> 2</b>:20 (teach and seduce)? So even from a grammatical,
syntactical standpoint, does teach and exercise authority mean teach
authoritatively like an elder.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1 Timothy 2:12</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> syntax</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) Is </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
the implied common object of </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
and </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) Is </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
the object of </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>only?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek uses
case endings to indicate grammatical functions in a sentence. (a) We would not expect
a noun to be the common object of a compound-verb construction if the verbs
govern different cases. The bail out might be to use the case required by the
nearer verb. In 1 Timothy<b> 2</b>:12, </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
governs the accusative while </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
governs the genitive. (b) To teach and to exercise authority have five
words between them, which may separate them. A counter-consideration is that </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>(I
do not allow) stands between the infinitives to teach and to exercise
authority. (c) The two infinitives are connected by </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
meaning neither, rather than and. But </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
should probably not be considered any more disjunctive than </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>is;
it is its parallel negative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> These three things
might imply that teach means I do not allow women to teachperiod But Paul is
describing a public setting, so custom may still create an cultural expectancy that
women not teach in such a situation; it would be perceived as authoritative
regardless of the grammatical aspects of this sentence. In addition, the
comments in <b>2</b>:12 feed off into qualifications for elders, the highest
office in the local church, one of whose main roles is teaching. So Paul is
likely speaking about official teaching; that is, as elders would do. Teaching
younger women how to love their husbands (Titus <b>2</b>:4), teaching children
(2 Timothy<b> 1</b>:5), or teaching anyone informally (Acts <b>18</b>:26?) does
not fall under his perview. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1 Timothy 2:12</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> What does </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>mean:
silence, peacefulness, quietness?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
alternative is argued for by Joseph M. Webb in Where Is the Command to
Silence? <i>Christian Standard</i>, May 21, 1989, p 4. Cyril of Jerusalem in <i>Prochetechesis
14</i> cited by Michael Slusser in<i> Society of Biblical Literature</i>,
III:3 (Fall, 1992), p. 499, says the women were to read silently during the
pre-baptismal exorcisms. The most natural meaning refers to what contrasts with
what Paul says should not happen. He does not particularize it to a certain
setting like the pre-baptismal observation just noted.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1 Timothy 2:13</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>Adam
was formed first, then Eve.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>Adam
was informed first, then Eve.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Walt Kaiser
offered the second translation in Shared Leadership, <i>Christianity Today</i>,
October 3, 1986. We know from the Genesis account that the first rendering is
true, so we can accept that and let the other idea be a matter of interest.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1 Timothy 3:2</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> article</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Husband of
one wife lacks the article, which draws attention to the kind of person he is;
hence, it sets up the possibility for other morally acceptable statuses besides
married men were possible: that a previously divorced man, a man who had never found
a mate (bachelor), most obviously a man whose wife had died (widower), or one
that had then remarried (deuterogamist).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%'><img width=222 height=239
id="Picture 4" src="/cir-library/images/essays/greek-helps-in-new-testament-interpretation/image003.png"
alt="A diagram of a diagram&#10;&#10;Description automatically generated with medium confidence"></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The same
comments apply to <b>3</b>:12, where Paul mentions this characteristic for
deacons, and to Titus <b>1</b>:6, where the phrase appears again in reference
to elders. Titus <b>1</b>:6-7 makes this clear by putting the word blameless
before and after husband of one wife. He has character in mind, not societal
status. This idea is what one-woman man intends to address.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>1 Timothy 3:11</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>refer
to the wives (of deacons) or to women (deaconesses)?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Relevant
passages include Titus <b>1</b>:6 and 1 Timothy <b>5</b>:9. See also the
following excerpt from Virgil Warrens M.A. thesis.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> From Romans <b>16</b>:1;
1 Timothy<b> 3</b>:11; <b>5</b>:3-16 some exegetes have defended the existence
of deaconesses in the early church. As respects the larger question of the
positive New Testament pattern for church unity, this problem need not be
solved. If 1 Timothy <b>3</b>:11 speaks of deaconesses under the word </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
mentioning them amid statements about deacons makes deaconess not so much a
separate function, as a sub-category on the same function: service to the
Christian community. Certain services to female members could more properly be
fulfilled by women or by husbands (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
and wives (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>) together. The
relationship between deacon and deaconess could be as follows.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
qualifications for deacons in 1 Timothy <b>3</b>:8-10 + 12-13 inserts the
material in question between two sections about deacons. In 3:12 we do not find
men but deacons, which implies that Paul has not left his description of
deacons in <b>3</b>:11. It suggests that he is thinking of </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
as the wives of the deacons described in the surrounding verses. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In Romans <b>16</b>:1,
however, Phoebe is called a </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
of the church in Cenchrea. She was going to Rome in some kind of service work. That
sounds like she was not a deaconess in combination with her husband, but as
someone on her own who would be doing for Roman Christians what she was doing
in Cenchrea. Of note, however, is that she was going to Rome to do this
service; she was not going there to be part of the organization of the church
there. We would not think she would have been going to Rome without her husband
if she had one. So her efforts <u>there</u> were not official because she was
not part of the organization of any congregation in Rome. Phoebes case may be
a crossover with older widows envisioned in contrast to younger ones in 1
Timothy <b>5</b>:9-16. Older widows supported by the church evidently had
responsibilities they could perform in return for their support. There seems to
be no sure exegetical base on which to build a case for the presence of
official deaconesses in the first-century church, though nothing critical is at
stake in the matter.</span></p>

style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The text says
not to neglect the gift that . . . was given . . . <u>with</u> the laying on of
the hands of the presbytery. It does not say <i>given <u>by</u> the laying on
of the hands of the presbytery.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The passage
relates to the question of whether anyone except an apostle could pass on
miraculous gifts. 1 Timothy <b>1</b>:6 says that Timothys gift was received
from the laying on of Pauls hands. Laying on here must refer to Timothys
ordination/commissioning; anything more is uncertain because we do not see him
working any miracles in the biblical record. The gift, then, that Paul is
referring to is Timothys slot of service.</span></p>

<i>vs</i>. no commas [restrictive <i>vs</i>. non-restrictive God-breathed]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> placement
of</span> <u>is</u></p>
