0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'> <u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%'>and</span></u><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%'> </span><i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>vs</span></i><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%'>. <u>also</u></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><u><span style='text-decoration:none'>&nbsp;</span></u></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'> <span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Two wordings seem
to fit the context, which shows Pauls concern to encourage Timothy in a good
thing:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>All/every
scripture (is) God-breathed and profitable.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>All/every
scripture, God-breathed, (is) also
profitable.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> 
(being) God-breathed,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (because
it is) God-breathed [NON-RESTRICTIVE]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> As to the
placement of the <u>linking verb</u>, it might be noted that there is no other
New Testament instance where an attributive adjective is connected with a
predicate adjective by the word </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>;
that is, </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> is used to connect equal
and parallel grammatical features unless it is adverbial. Compare 1 Timothy <b>4</b>:4,
<i>Every created-thing is good and nothing to be rejected.</i> Also Hebrews<b>
4</b>:12, <i>The word of God is living and active and sharper than any
two-edged sword. </i>If the copulative verb is place</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
after God-breathed, the interpreter needs to understand God-breathed as a
non-restrictive element set off in commas <i>Scripture, being God-breathed, is
profitable</i>; <i>all scripture, because it is God-breathed, (is) also
profitable</i> (except for the observation made above about the awkwardness of
combining attributive and predicate adjectives with </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
is never used of a non-authoritative scripture in the New Testament.
Consequently, its meaning a writing would be to do something we would not
expect. Since Paul is speaking about what Lois, Eunice, and Timothy would have
considered normative, it is doubtful whether writing in a general sense could
have any relevance. Besides, the apostle has just used the word in a technical
sense in the preceding verse.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In choosing
between all and every, we might observe that the plural </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
occurs in <b>3</b>:15, thus individuating the whole into its parts. On the
other hand, Paul says scripture is profitable for several things. He links them
by </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> rather than </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
(or), which he might have used if he were thinking of individuated scriptures.
Not every scripture would be profitable for each of these things. It might be
possible to speak this way because he was individuating them and using <u>and</u>
to connect the many possibilities a scripture might have.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
translation God-breathed is better than inspired because its word picture
is that of exhaling the scripture. <i></i><u>Inspired</u> creates the picture
of something already in existence from some other source and then God breathed
into it (as into Adam), and it became something more, something that has an
added character (authoritative, approved, <i>etc</i>.).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A series of
words has been used traditionally to state from various angles the character of
scripture in positive and negative terms. The list begins with the biblical
expression in 2 <br>
Timothy<b> 3</b>:16, which translates literally as God-breathed. The rather
unhappy term in popular vogue for this passage is inspired so that
inspiration becomes the noun employed to get at the Pauline concept expressed
in the text. Inspire, however, does not properly picture the idea intended
because it (a) creates the image of breathing into something already existent
an added character, as noted above. The word-picture in God-breathed is that
of exhaling the thing itself so that the scripture is viewed as issuing from
the mouth of God directly; consequently, scripture is by definition set apart
from all other examples of writing in that it may be viewed as Gods speaking.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A second
weakness in inspire for theopneustos is that it (b) leaves less clear that
the quality in mind characterizes the <u>writing</u> rather than the <u>writer</u>.
So it does not sufficiently contrast revelation with illumination, the
heightened power of perception or understanding that might be generated in/by a
mans mind as he views the Old Testament. Men are illuminated; the message is
revealed. Illumination is limited to what is theoretically possible to see so
that it does not eliminate error necessarily in all whereof one might speak.
Inspiration does not offset the subtle change in modern theology of the Bible
that shifts the quality from the scripture to the scribe, and then proceeds to
view the nature of inspiration as something analogous to the inspiration of
an artist, poet, musician. God-breathedness draws attention to the relationship
between scripture and God and then to the implicit qualities of that
association.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

18.0pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>

alt="A close-up of a diagram&#10;&#10;Description automatically generated"></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> As a word, <u>inspire</u>
could be an inspired <u>man</u>, who is really grabbed by a situation and writes
a <u>book</u> that is inspired because it reflects the authors really being
grabbed by that situation so that the <u>reader</u> is inspired as well. The
book is inspired because it is inspiring.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The lack of
an article on scripture tends to emphasize the character of scripture rather
than scripture as an identity.</span></p>

sanctifier and the sanctified (are) all of one [father].</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> In <b>2</b>:9-18
the writer speaks of the need to become a physical man to participate in the
full range of human experienceincluding suffering unto deathin order to
qualify himself in full righteousness to be appointed as savior of humankind.
Consequently, we are inclined to understand <b>2</b>:11 as an anticipation of
those comments; that means opting for all of one nature.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> See <i>What
the Bible Says About Salvation</i>, p. 59.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does the
indefinite adverb imply that the writer does not know.? It says, Somewhere it
says thus about the seventh day. Another translation is <i>In a certain place
it says . . . . .</i> Luke <b>12</b>:20; <b>16</b>:4, 9 shows that indefinites
do not imply lack of knowledge. In this passage then </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
does not imply that the Hebrew writer did not know the source of his quotation.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Sometimes

in the place of the bush</i> (Mark <b>12</b>:26), as well as references to
authors like Isaiah, Jeremiah,<i> etc</i>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The meaning
of <u>tempt</u> ranges from being presented with a testsomething God even
invites his people to do in Malachi <b>3</b>:1)to trying to get people to
depart from their ethical standards. In another set of variables, <u>tempt</u>
runs from being presented with a temptation that holds no lure for the one
tempted all the way to successful temptation. The Holy Spirit could be tempted
(Acts <b>5</b>:9) in the sense of tested. Elsewhere God is said to be tempted
even within Hebrews itself: <b>3</b>:9 &lt; Psalm <b>95</b>:9. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Gods not being
able to be tempted with evil (James <b>1</b>:13) has nothing to do with denying
the deity of Christ, who was tempted. He was tempted <u>in the flesh</u>
because incarnation made him susceptible to physical drives and pain like the people
have that he came to save, yet without sin (<b>4</b>:15). The point lies in the
fact that Christ was in the flesh and could be tempted through the it.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Can this word
cover both impossible and improbable? Can it cover impossible in different
senses: not possible from a practical standpoint, as a behavioral observation
about people;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> not possible
from a theoretical standpoint; God will not accept them back?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Greek may not
have as wide a vocabulary for gradations of possibility as English has. Maybe a
particularly hard experience later can bring a person to his senses. Gods not being
willing to accept him back does not sound like what would happen in an
interpersonal process with a loving God. So we are inclined to take the verse
as a comment on a sad tendency that still leaves open unlikely possibilities.
It allows for James <b>5</b>:19-20 to carry its natural import<i>: If any
among you err from the truth and one convert him, let him know that he who
converts a sinner will save a soul from death and cover a multitude of sins. </i>Similarly,
Jude 22-23 comments, <i>On some have mercy who are in doubt; some, save,
snatching them out of the fire; and on some have mercy with apprehension.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) to nibble
at <i>vs</i>. consume</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) to
experience something in a perceptive way</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
wording is more likely here. The author uses the same figure earlier when he
says that Jesus tasted of death for every person (<b>2</b>:9). The import of
the passage would hardly mean a light exposure (from which the person could
fall away) <i>vs</i>. a full intake (from which God would keep him from falling
away as in the doctrine of perseverance of the saints). Besides tasting the
heavenly gift, the good word of God, and the powers of the coming age (<b>6</b>:4-5),
the person envisioned has been enlightened and partaken of the Holy Spirit.
That is a strong line-up of Christian experiences to which it would be
difficult to add anything relevant.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Other
passages on tasting as perceptive are Matthew <b>16</b>:28; Mark <b>9</b>:1;
Luke <b>9</b>:27; <b>14</b>:24; John <b>2</b>:9; <b>8</b>:52; Colossians <b>2</b>:21;
Psalms <b>34</b>:8; 1 Peter <b>2</b>:3. In fact, only Matthew<b> 27</b>:34
appears to use taste without stressing the acute perception of the
experience.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The first
option is best because it leaves the statement as ambiguous in English as the
participle does in Greek. The third option does not make a lot of sense: if we
could get a person to stop crucifying the Son of God all over again, we would
be getting him to repent. It sounds like Mom telling her little boy how to
catch a bird: put salt on its tail. If you could get close enough to put salt
on its tail, you would not need to put salt on its tail. The reason for various
options here, comes from interacting with the doctrine of perseverance of the
saints. See <i>What the Bible Says About Salvation</i>, pp. 451-53, 486-95.</span></p>

created by </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>[</span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>]
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
If taken regarding Sarah as subject, the [</span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>]
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>if
it appearsremains an appositive with the subject, which is less problematic,
or unusual. From an information standpoint, it seems better to make Sarah the
one who received power since we know she was barren. Abraham, however, had
begotten Ishmael, only fourteen years before and later had six sons by a second
wifeKeturah. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> As counters
to these considerations, we do note that the Hebrews text goes on to say in <b>11</b>:12
that Abraham was as good as dead. Maybe that point could be in light of his
aged wifes barrenness. Similarly, counting him faithful who had promised is
more easily connected with Abraham since God dealt primarily with him.
Nevertheless, the angel did talk directly to Sarah. When the angel talked to
her, she laughed, which may look away from counting God faithful; yet her
laughing was not a permanent attitude.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrews 11:32</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> masculine
particle</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The masculine
participle modifying shows that a woman could not have written Hebrews even
though Harnack suggested that Priscilla wrote the book.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrews 12:2</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> objective
genitive</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>author
and perfecter of</i><b> </b>[our/his] <i>faith</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Is this
objective genitive (the faithfulness that Jesus perfected) or (the faith/trust
that he perfects in us)? We would think that the author and perfecter would
both lead into faith the same way. If so, then he is the author of <u>our</u>
faith and therefore the perfecter the writer is talking about is <u>our</u>
faith as well.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrews 12:2</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> When the
writer says that on the cross Jesus despised the shame, does he mean it in a
negative or neutral sense? Does he mean hated the shamefulness (negative) or
disregarded (neutral) it because of the glory that was set before him. The
second option sounds like Pauls observation, <i>The sufferings of this
present time are not worth comparing with the glory that will be revealed to
us.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrews 12:17</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> ellipsis</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> he found no
place for a change of heart [in his father]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> [in
himself]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The former is
surely the meaning because the text goes on to say, <i>though </i>[Esau]<i>
sought it diligently with tears.</i> The description sounds like there was
some kind of change in himself. The other idea is that he could not bring
himself to repent, an interesting idea in itself, but not one that comes
through clearly in the flow of thought.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrews 13:4 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>indicative/imperative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>(Let)
the bed not (be) defiled.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>The bed
(is) not defiled.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The verb the
reader is to supply is surely the imperative, because the wording continues
with reminders about what God will do to those who disobey his directives on
the matter.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>Hebrews 13:24</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> vocabulary</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>[<i>The
ones from Italy salute you.</i>]</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> It cannot
mean <i>they salute you from Italy</i> because the prepositional phrase stands
in an adjective slot after the article.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A comparable
case appears in Acts<b> 17</b>:13, however: <i>When the Jews from Thessalonia
knew that the word of God was preached by Paul in Berea . . . .</i> The text
reads, </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
They were not away from Thessalonica when they heard but were from/of
Thessalonica.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A fourfold
example shows up with Joseph of Arimathea in Matthew <b>27</b>:57; Mark <b>15</b>:43;
Luke <b>23</b>:51; and John <b>19</b>:38. All four writers say </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
Their point is not that Joseph was away from Arimathea, but that he originated
from that town. It is obvious from the narrative that Joseph was in Jerusalem, so
he was from Arimathea; the writer would not, in reporting events in
Jerusalem, be telling their readers Joseph was away from Arimathea by being in
Jerusalem.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> John <b>1</b>:44
reports that Philip was from Bethsaida (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>),
Andrew and Peters city. Surely again, the point is not that Philip was away
from Bethsaida; that was clear from the narrative.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> There are
three options then: </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1)
Italians with Paul in Italy as he writes to elsewhere,</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2)
Italians with Paul sending greeting back home to wherever, or</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (3)
Italians with Paul sending greetings to a third place.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The third
option seems unlikely. Why would the writer single out people from Rome in
writing from where he was in some second place while sending greetings to
people in some third place.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
option does not seem likely either because in early Christian tradition,
Hebrews is not witnessed as being sent to Rome.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The first
option makes the best sense. Telling his readership that those beside him were
sending them greetings would be natural. It indicates then that the author is
writing from Rome.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span></p>

</span>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:center'><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>James 1:19</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> imperative/indicative</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>Know
this.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>You
know this.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The
imperative seems more likely; there would be little reason to tell his readers
that they know what they know they know, You must be swift to listen.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>James 2:10</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> translation</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
<i>He has become guilty of all. </i>The comment sounds like the author means
the offender is considered guilty of breaking every one of the other
commandments when he breaks just one. The plural all tends to sound that way
too, admittedly. If it were singular, it would more easily fit with the notion
that offenders have become guilty of the Law as such, as a whole. Our
inclination is to fall back on that composite idea even though all is plural.
The thought would be that the offender has become guilty of them all clustered.
It is too difficult to imagine someone being guilty of the many other things he
has not done. As it is, perhaps the point could be taken as meaning that he in
principle would break the other commandments too since disrespect for God in
breaking one applies equally to them all.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>James 2:14</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> question</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>implies
a negative answer; </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> would have implied a
positive answer.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> <i>Can belief
save him?</i> would have been an informational question, but that translation
does not account for the negative in the Greek sentence, <i>Belief cannot save
him, can it?</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>James 2:14 </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>demonstrative?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1) <i>Faith
cannot save him, can it?</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2) <i>(That)
faith cannot save him, can it?</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The first
translation is the correct one because (a) that does not appear in the Greek.
(b) James subsequent contrast is between faith and works, not between one kind
of faith and anotherbetween a faith that works and a faith that does not.
Interpreters may want to add the demonstrative in an effort to harmonize James
teaching on faith and works with Pauls teaching about faith and works. And
that may seem to fit the immediate context (<b>2</b>:14) because it refers to someone
that wants to say he has faith (that is, without works) while the one he is
talking to has workstwo alternatives, right? <i>Were both good. I believe
the right stuff; that is what being a Christian can mean. You do the right
stuff; that is another thing being a Christian can mean. Were both safe/saved.</i></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> As an idea,
these interpreters proposal at the beginning of the last paragraph will fit
in, but it is not exactly what James is teaching. (a) First, James is talking
about faith as something demons have (<b>2</b>:19). The faith they have does
not relate to saving them; so it does not equal the speakers claim in <b>2</b>:14,
where he proposes that some saved people have one thing going for them
(faith) while others have something else going for them (works). Alls good
here. But James says, No.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (b) Second,
James goes on to say that Abraham was justified by works when he offered up
Isaac (<b>2</b>:21) and Rahab by sending the spies out another way (<b>2</b>:25).
He was justified, not by his act, but by God as conditioned on his act.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (c) Thirdly, in
talking about justification, James does not talk about a faith/belief <u>that</u>
works, but about faith/belief <u>and</u> works. Salvation comes from Gods
reckoning the combination, not from one (faith/belief) that produces the
other (works). For James purposes, he conceptualizes them as two things (<b>2</b>:20,
21, 22, 23, 24, 26). He conceptualizes the process as one plus the other that leads
to Gods doing the justifying (by reckoning: <b>2</b>:23). </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> That prepares
the way for an important point: for saying that both faith and worksbelieving something
and doing somethinghave a relationship to the resulting salvation/reckoning/justifying.
A person cannot take credit for believing any more than he can take create
for doing. Both faith/belief and works/doing in James 2 are conditions, not
causes. The cause of justification occurs in the mind and will of God, who acts
by giving the salvation result: God reckons people like Abraham as righteous on
the basis of faith/trust/believing and works/doing-something. James attention
to the human side of the salvation process corresponds with the Book of James
as wisdom literature.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> As another
note in this segment on James 2, we note our decision <i>The Conversational
Version </i>to translate </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>in
James as belief rather than faith. Doing so uses the that </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
proposal above, but in a specific way: James is talking about belief, which is
different from the faith/trust that appears in Paul. That kind of </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
translated belief, cannot save anybody; just remember that Paul does not use
the word that way. The difference between our proposal and the previous one
above is that proposal speaks of a kind of <u>faith</u> whereas ours speaks of
a different meaning of the <u>word</u> </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Plugging that
construction into the larger picture, we see the full reality as an
interpersonal one: what the human person does (believing and doing) and what
the divine person does (justifying).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Aspect One
(James)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Final
note regarding James construction of (the human side of) the interpersonal salvation
process that takes place within a conditionality framework. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> A condition can
be called an occasional cause <i>vs.</i> an efficient cause or even a
contributory cause. An occasional cause does not produce anything; it only
provides a circumstance in which the efficient cause appropriately produces it.
The efficient cause is divine forgiveness; the occasional is human believing-and-doing.
That is the part James lays out in the salvation process: essentially the human
side of the larger interpersonal process. It has the character Jesus
illustrates with looking on a brazen serpent for the cure of snakebite (John <b>3</b>:14-15).
Looking at anything does not cure snakebite. James believing is an
interpersonal believing, and his doing is an interpersonal doing; it is not
just any believing or any doing. It morphs into trusting. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Aspect Two
(Paul)</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>  The
rest of the full interpersonal process is that by our believing-doing
combination we connect ourselves to Christ-the-righteous-Ones atonement as the
way of identifying-with-him/commitment-to-him. On that condition, God has
willed to reckon us as righteous like him (forgive sins)on our commitment to
him who <u>is</u> righteous. Aspect Two transforms Aspect One by a
contextualizing clarification.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> **We
need to make one adjustment to this broad comparison to Paul in Romans and
Galatians. In James </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> means belief
whereas it means belief-trust in Paul. Note the wording in <i>The
Conversational Version</i> in the respective scripture portions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> When
the rest of the picture gets placed in the hologram, it clarifies James
teaching by interpersonalizing the believing and doing. James believing is an
interpersonal believing, and his doing is an interpersonal doing. It is not
just any kind of believing, but a believing within a personal relationship; and
it is not just any kind of doing, but a doing within a personal relationship.
Contextualizing Aspect One by putting it in Aspect Two not only adds the rest
of the picture; it transforms the first part of the picture into an
interpersonal kind of process (Jeremiah <b>31</b>s new kind of covenant
written on the heart).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>&nbsp;</span></p>

the Bible Says About Salvation</i>, pp. 218-19.</span></p>

translates this faults, which serves as a basis then for a distinction in <i>The
Good News of the World Tomorrow</i> (May-June, 1988, p. 23) between <u>faults</u>
and sins. The writer of the article is trying to argue against sacerdotalism on
the basis of this word slip.</span></p>

you may be healed.</span></i><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> This is not indirect discourse, but
purpose because it flows from a purpose clause.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (1)
one-directional, thus leaving the door open for </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> (2)
two-directional between peers</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> James puts
this directive inside a set of examples that show what he means: pray for one
another that you may be healed, a remedying process between persons. The
interpretation of this directives meaning must derive from systematic groundsfrom
the whole picture. An unclear passage cannot serve as the basis for a doctrine
or practice. If the passage by itself can be taken in more than one way, its
meaning must derive from the full picture in which it stands. Eliminating
legalism eliminates distinctive ideas rooted in itideas like authoritarian,
legal operation. The ones that fit with interpersonal considerations are the
only ones left standing.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The argument has

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
to announce, not </span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:
115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>,
to preach the gospel. Therefore, it means to announce to the spirits the
accomplishment of the salvation program, which amounts to sealing their doom.
It did not invite them to accept salvation. The conclusion is agreeable, but
this observation does not serve as a satisfactory basis for it. See below.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> But 1 Peter <b>4</b>:6
speaks of this same incident evidently, yet the text uses </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>in
speaking about preaching the gospel to the dead. Furthermore, using </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

does not mean it was not for invitation purposes; in 2 Peter <b>2</b>:5 Noah is

</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>may
have relevance, however, to the fact that in 1 Peter <b>3</b> the former is
used when discussing the <u>disobedient</u> souls in prison from the days of
Noahevidently a presentative groupwhile the latter is used when discussing
the dead to be judged like the living. But terminology-based arguments are
often tenuous. Mark <b>16</b>:15, for example, says </span><span lang=EL
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span

</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>
</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>parallels
</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>.
It can be used in connection with the preaching enterprise.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The second
reference may have to do with those, say, Israelites already regarded by God as
saved on the basis of the previous revelation he had given them through Moses
and the prophets (Luke <b>16</b>:29). They were now being apprised of the
historical accomplishment of the real basis on which their salvation rested.
Such a thing reminds us of Jesus discussion with Moses and Elijah on the Mount
of Transfiguration in which they were talking about his exodus. Hebrews <b>9</b>:15
indicates that the salvation of people during the Mosaic dispensation really
rests in Jesus Christ. By the same principle of operation, we assume God
figures salvation and lostness for those in the patriarchal dispensation before
Moses.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Scripture does
make clear that peoples final condition becomes their eternal state. Ezekiel <b>18</b>:18,
24; John <b>8</b>:21, 24, 28 use the expression <i>die in your sins.</i> That
factor from elsewhere guides the choice for interpreting here about preaching
to the spirits in prison.</span></p>

0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Is the love
of God something (a) we have for him as demonstrated by keeping his
commandments without feeling grieved (put upon) by doing so, or is the love
of God something (b) he has for us that enables us to keep his commandments
without feeling grieved in doing so?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:-9.0pt;margin-bottom:
0in;margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> The preceding
context sets the direction presumably because we are the ones acting in those
earlier verses; yet it is an engaging thought that Gods loving us does not
particularly have a miraculous implication to it.</span></p>

line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> Does sin
unto death (</span><span lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span lang=EL style='font-size:
12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'> </span><span
lang=EL style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'></span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>)
mean (1) degree, (2) duration, or (3) consequence? Is the emphasis on how long
it lastsand therefore characteristic action, action going on till the end of
life (which determines eternal destiny), or is the emphasis on the result? In
the last case, we would not pray for the forgiveness of someone whose sin is
obviously not to be forgiven either because he is characteristically doing it
or because it is so obvious not going to be forgiven. </span></p>
